—My question is directed to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to his statement yesterday that he had not received advice from Treasury about the ongoing deterioration of the world economy and the threat that that deterioration presents to the Government's economic growth forecasts. I also refer the Treasurer to a report in today's Australian Financial Review that just such a Treasury assessment was given to the Government on 23 September. I ask the Treasurer: is this report accurate, and why did he conceal its existence when asked about it yesterday?

—The question that the honourable member asked me yesterday concerned an assessment of the world economy. I have received no such assessment of the world economy which would lead me, or indeed lead the Treasury, to change the estimates or forecasts for growth this year. Yes, it is true that the Treasury provided, as it does on a continuing basis, information about developments within the domestic economy. Much of the contents of that note I included in my response to the honourable member yesterday.

PARA.TAB: There was nothing very startling about it. It said that since the Budget the housing sector had been stronger than had been predicted and that maybe the rural sector would be little weaker than had been predicted. But it did not go to the topic which the honourable member seems to be preoccupied with—that is, the question of the international economy and its effect on our growth forecasts.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the Minister inform the House of the reaction of the wheat industry to the recent announcement about the new wheat marketing arrangements? Also, why did the Government reject price underwriting?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Page for his question. The industry response to the Government's announcement of last week has been extremely positive. The package itself represents an important step forward for the industry. It involves phasing out of government support by 1999, whilst providing the framework for growth and the development of a more vertically integrated industry. It recognises that the future for our wheat industry lies in a freer world trading environment and a greater commitment to do more than just trade the commodity.

PARA.TAB: In this package the Government has also had regard for the particular circumstances confronting the industry by agreeing to maintain the export monopoly for the Australian Wheat Board in the absence of a conclusion to the Uruguay Round. This recognises that in a world trading environment which is corrupted by the lunacy of massive EC and US subsidies the monopoly provides our most effective mechanism to protect the interests of our growers. I might say that pessimistic media reports this morning about US-EC talks in Brussels appear to be premature. The real challenge at this critical stage is the exercise of a political will at the highest level to achieve an outcome prior to the US presidential elections next month. That remains possible, in my view, because it is in President Bush's strongest interests to push for such a conclusion.

As part of the package, the GCA, the Grains Council of Australia, has agreed that that monopoly position should be reviewed subject to the progress in the Uruguay Round. In fact, the whole package has the agreement of the Grains Council of Australia. This is another example of this Government's capacity to work with industry and to get industry agreement to achieve growth strategies within the broader discipline of phasing down government support.

The fact is that the Opposition could not have developed this outcome. The package itself is not policy by edict; it is not driven by the textbook. The Government is consulting with and working policy out with industry, and industry has recognised that.
So far as the industry comment is concerned, there are reams of support for this package from the industry itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of concerns in the tourism industry of proposals to impose new taxes on tourism in Australia? Is the Prime Minister confident that the tourism industry will continue to grow in Australia as one of our major export earners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The freedoms which the Government introduced to the economy in the 1980s saw the tourism industry blossom in such a way that 2.4 million people visited Australia in 1991. That is up over 155 per cent on the figure eight years earlier. In fact, tourism now accounts for 10 per cent of our total export earnings. My colleague the Minister for Tourism, in his national tourism strategy, indicated that 200,000 additional jobs can be created in this industry alone by the year 2000. That is, this industry is an efficient industry but it has a relatively high labour content. It is now one of Australia's biggest export earners, and is growing rapidly.

PARA.TAB: The Government has done a lot to promote the industry with reforms to aviation, by promotion through the tourism commission, by changes to tax treatment of buildings, plant and equipment in the tourism sectors and, of course, by developments in roads, et cetera. But, of course, the Opposition wants to tax the tourism industry with a 15 per cent goods and services tax. No wonder the industry is up in arms. The coalition is saying it wants to take the burden off industry, particularly export industries; yet it intends to impose a 15 per cent tax. I was very interested in what Mr John Dart, the President of the Australian Federation of Travel Agents, had to say recently:

ANSWER.PARA: A lot of our members are small operators, and particularly up in the Northern Territory, which is a good example, where there are a lot of little guys with three and four Land Rovers, if you like small mini-buses, and doing a great job.
He went on to say:

But with Fightback there are no offsets. There are no offsets in terms of the Fightback package because there is no payroll tax offset, and in many cases there is nothing else. So in essence the price of their product is going up by 10 per cent.

Mr Speaker, you will notice in the advertisements which the Opposition is now running on television that I am depicted in a factory. The scam is that of the 700,000 businesses in this country, only 100,000 pay payroll tax, so the other 600,000 would receive no benefit by way of payroll tax reduction—no benefit. You will notice that it is a relatively large factory, because if it was put in a relatively small factory it would have been a distortion of the fact that it would have received any payroll tax offset.

PARA.TAB: This person is making the claim that most of the small tourism operators around Australia will get no payroll tax relief at all; in fact, most small businesses will get no payroll tax relief under the Fightback package; they will just wear the GST as a principal burden. He goes on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: Look, I am going to ignore this because our families represent 500,000 workers and we have got families, possibly 1 1/2 million people who are affected . . . Many tourists would prefer to travel to destinations such as Bali, Fiji or Singapore than travel within Australia under Fightback because they will wear the 15 per cent tax.
Then we had this question from the Opposition spokesman for tourism, the honourable member for Fadden, in October 1991:
I ask you, is it fair if you apply a GST to a loaf of bread and you don't apply it to a holiday in Hawaii?

That is a very good question. There was a report commissioned between the Australian Tourism Industry Association and the coalition, which is signed by the honourable member and Mr O'Clery. It says this:

However, the Australian tourism industry and all members of the coalition ATIA joint committee believe that measures must be adopted to mitigate the adverse relative price impacts of the GST package on Australian tourism industry operators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who signed that?
—This is signed by David Jull and Peter O'Clery.
—Order! The honourable member for Macarthur!
—They recommend a series of measures. The document goes on in a similar vein, and it quotes Ernst and Young:

ANSWER.PARA: Overall it is a labour intensive value adding service operation often delivered by a small business. The Australian tourism industry is likely to incur a relatively large one-off cost and price impact on the implementation of the GST. The industry understands that it does not relish the prospect from its own perspective.

They then in this report articulate a series of proposals to help the industry—none can help remove the 15 per cent GST impact. One suggestion is that Australian tour packages prepurchased overseas by international visitors should be zero rated, so that if an international tourist who comes to Australia buys the package out of the United States it is zero rated. The Opposition will not zero rate food, but it will zero rate tourist packages or consider it.

PARA.TAB: The report then talks about the deductibility of legitimate business expenses. The Opposition wants to get onto that old ramp again, as if in any way that can deal with the problem's source, which is a 15 per cent tax on hotel rooms and every service delivered in the tourism sector, including flights. Then it goes on to talk about depreciation:

ANSWER.PARA: The Committee unanimously agrees that depreciation allowances should as far as possible reflect effective economic life. To this end, the Committee recommends that short term traveller accommodation be subject to an amortisation rate of 7 1/2 per cent rather than the present 4.

Will that help someone with four Land Rovers in the Northern Territory? Will it help someone who already has a hotel? Will it help anybody who already has a building? In other words, what you are saying to the big hotel groups is, `We'll go along with the fiction that you can write a hotel off in 13 or 14 years and we will pay that from the Commonwealth Treasury so you can pay money into our political slush fund'. That is what that is about; it is not about helping anyone in the tourism sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you increase the rate from 2.5 per cent to 4 per cent?

—The Leader of the Opposition is asking why I increased the rate from 2 1/2 to 4 per cent. I will explain it slowly for him: 4 per cent into 100 equals 25 years—a 25-year amortisation. That is not 13 for a building. I notice that the Hooker Corporation said recently:

ANSWER.PARA: In the case of traveller accommodation, the combined effect of the One Nation changes—
that is, that 2.5 to 4 per cent—
and lower inflation is to increase the real value of depreciation write-offs by a massive 116 per cent.
It concluded:
It is therefore an important observation that in present value terms investment in plant, buildings and equipment is now far less costly than was the case 12 months ago.

That is, the real value of depreciation written off by 116 per cent; yet the Leader of the Opposition is considering jacking up the 4 per cent to 7 1/2 per cent to increase that 116 per cent more substantially. But it does not even deal with the problem at source, which is a 15 per cent tax on all tourism services across the country. All the people who have their hotels and motels and their tourist buses already as capital stock will have no relief from anything else. This would simply be a sop to the large hotels in the large hotel groups, presumably on the basis that they backhand the Liberal Party's financial position; in other words, `Let the Commonwealth Budget pay and you can give us recompense in our slush fund'. This will not do anything whatsoever for the tourism industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.
—In fact, the Leader of the Opposition wants to introduce a 15 per cent tax—

—which his own shadow Minister concedes will have adverse relative price impacts in the context of the GST package on Australian tourism for industry operators.

—He signed up to this report with ATIA saying that you have quite dastardly impacts here that will knock this fast growing sector of Australian commerce down, will knock its growth down, as they have to wear a large impact for which they cannot get recompense and they will have great difficulty off-loading the costs upon consumers.

That means that the GST is a dead cost to them—and not just a dead cost; they will spend their weekends computing it. Every Sunday will be spent computing it.
Opposition members—Lies! Lies!
Government members interjecting—

—The Liberal Party may lie through its teeth in its TV advertisements, but let all Australian small businesses know—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I give a general warning to members on my left that, if they use those types of interjections again, I will name them without warning.

—It is no wonder Mr Jull is nervous about the tourism industry. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Mr Hugh Morgan: Racial Discrimination Act

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister explain to the House the basis of the Government's response to the recent High Court decision in the Mabo case? Does the Government intend to change its approach to these fundamental issues in light of recent statements suggesting that the Mabo judgment was not soundly based and that the Racial Discrimination Act should be repealed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In what is a very historic decision, the High Court turned over the notion of terra nullius and declared that there was native title in Australia at the point of European colonisation, but a title which is subordinate to the Crown. The implications of that decision are far reaching. They are being studied and thought about by serious and sensible people around Australia, as I believe the Mabo case can provide a very firm basis for reconciliation in this country between the Aboriginal community and the non-Aboriginal community. I notice that this is not the view of at least one leading businessman in this country. I am speaking, of course, of Mr Hugh Morgan. He is one of those people who are defenders of what is right and proper.
—He is on your hit list.
—Order! The honourable member for Moore will cease interjecting.
—He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The High Court has plunged property law into chaos and given substance to the ambitions of Australian communists and the Bolshevik Left for a separate Aboriginal state with its recent decision on land rights.

He called on the coalition Government immediately to repeal the Racial Discrimination Act—apparently he wants racial discrimination—which underpins the High Court's recent decision. He went on to argue:

The doctrine of terra nullius applied not only to a newly discovered country which was uninhabited, but also when the inhabitants were at such a primitive state of development that no treaty with them was possible.
He said:
The Aboriginal community have no sense of time or history.
In explaining his view of the history of the Court's decision, he said:
A separate sovereign state for the Aborigines carved out of Australia had been a settled and constant ambition for the communists and Bolshevik Left generally in Australia for over 50 years.
He went on to say:
The claims by the Aboriginal community may be regarded by some as ridiculous, but the High Court has already given them substance.

This upholder of what is good and proper is attacking the High Court. Mr Morgan has always painted himself as a thoughtful thinker on the Right. He has never been thoughtful, and he has never been a thinker. What we have here is just bigotry. It is the voice of ignorance, the voice of hysteria and the voice of the nineteenth century.

PARA.TAB: Mr Hugh Morgan is the Managing Director of one of Australia's largest mining companies. It will not be long before we have the Australian Mining Industry Council coming to the Government saying, `Can't we settle all these issues down? Can't we responsibly deal with these problems?', when one of its major constituent leaders is running around talking about this sort of prejudicial and ignorant material which will do nothing but inflame this issue in Australia. Mr Morgan is working on the basis that the High Court has somehow has fallen in with communists and the Bolshevik Left. I did not think the Bolshevik Left existed in this country any more.
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. There is too much noise.

—The fact is that, with all the prejudice, banality and venality which Mr Morgan could muster, he went on to make the claim that no title should ever have been vested in the Aboriginal people, that they were a race that had no sense of history or of their own cultural being, that they could not be dealt with, that for all intents and purposes Australia was uninhabited before European settlement, and that the title which was adopted by those who settled in Australia was the only good title. The whole legacy of injustice and shame which has gone on since that time would be compounded by these disgraceful statements.

PARA.TAB: It will be Mr Morgan up at another right wing organisation giving vent to his views who will then be again requiring the Government to make certain that, in the afterwash of Mabo, mining company interests are taken into account. This will be a real issue. But is it helped by this sort of extravagant language? Has this sort of right wing prejudicial stuff helped?
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—This fellow has always been given credit as a thinker on the right. He has never been a thinker; it is just a prejudiced view. It is a prejudiced view which is very harming to Australian community relations which is totally intolerant and should be condemned out of hand by the Leader of the Opposition and everybody opposite.

—Order! The House will come to order.
—The fact is that with a goods and services tax—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

—You have asked it; you wear the answer. You have led with your chin; you wear the punch on the chin.

—Payroll tax raises $7 billion in this country; the GST raises $27 billion. The bulk of the GST's revenue comes from a tax on the value adding by labour. —Can you believe this!

—You have got that embarrassed, giggly, silly laugh, because you know that it is true.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have lost the plot.

—A 15 per cent tax is an enormous slug to the taxpayers of this country; it is over half of the income tax. None of it is given back in tax cuts. Seven billion of the $27 billion goes to relieve 100,000 businesses of the burden of payroll tax.
—They already pay indirect taxes. Don't you understand that?

—But the other 600,000 businesses who have paid the GST get no payroll tax relief.
—Hawkie was better than this. Bring back Hawke.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will cease interjecting.

—Also, the people who are paying tax on their clothing and their food do not get relief compared with those who get the relief on petrol excise. It will come from cutting into Government spending, including support for the unemployed, which the Leader of the Opposition has the temerity to ask about, and ripping back on payments to schools and transfer payments in the social security system.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

The Government would underwrite the scheme so that it would be viable both for the bank or financial institution and for the pensioner. —I take this opportunity to inform the House of the outcome of the visit I made to Japan, Singapore and Cambodia between 20 and 26 September. This overseas visit was my third since becoming Prime Minister. All three visits have been to Asia-Pacific countries. All three visits have helped put a sharper focus on Australia's relations with the region.

PARA.TAB: A primary objective of each visit has been to talk with other regional leaders about how we can work together to respond to the fluid outlook in the region. But, just as importantly, I have also wanted to underline to both Australian and foreign audiences how much the Australian economy has shifted towards an international orientation, especially an Asia-Pacific orientation; how much Australia has already achieved in the region; and how much our future depends on successfully carrying forward this engagement.

More than is sometimes appreciated, the Asia-Pacific region is in the midst of a period of profound transition. The strategic consequences of the end of the Cold War are still working themselves out. The regional security outlook is generally favourable, but less predictable than before. The peace process in Cambodia, which involves an ambitious role for the United Nations, confronts a serious test of its sustainability.

Fluidity in the international trading environment is increased by uncertainty about the outcome of the Uruguay Round. Whatever the outcome of the round, we shall probably see an increasing trend towards regional, subregional, and bilateral trade arrangements. Regional governments are now required to develop policy responses to what could well be a rapidly evolving pattern of trade alignments. Asia-Pacific countries also need to consider how international and regional institutions can better reflect the growing weight of the region in world affairs, and the increasing importance of intra-regional linkages.

My visit to Japan was very worth while in consolidating with the Japanese Government the strong community of interest we have with it in responding to these important questions. The Australian public understands very well Japan's significance in our external relations. Japan is the world's second largest national economy, accounting for about 14 per cent of global output. It has been our largest trading partner since 1970.

Perhaps more than is generally appreciated in this country, Australia is also an important regional partner of Japan. We are Japan's third largest source of imports and sixth largest trading partner. The bilateral trade relationship, now worth around $A24 billion, is one of the principal sinews of economic interdependence in the western Pacific.

The close dialogue between the two governments on regional and international issues reflects the habit of friendship and cooperation that has grown up between the two countries in recent years. Certainly, the warmth of my reception by the Japanese Government and the quality of my discussions with Prime Minister Miyazawa and his Ministers attest to the maturity of the relationship that we now enjoy with Japan.

The comments of Mr Miyazawa and his Ministers reflected, I think, a realistic view of the international scene. There was cautious optimism that the Japanese economy would return to a stronger growth path from the end of this year. There was a determination, which I supported, that Japan should play a more active role in international affairs. I affirmed Australian support for Japan's permanent membership of the United Nations Security Council so that the world body can better reflect changed world circumstances. I welcomed Japan's decision to participate in United Nations peacekeeping operations and the opportunity this provides for our military and civilian personnel to work together in support of the Cambodia peace process.

I discussed international and bilateral trade issues with both Prime Minister Miyazawa and International Trade and Industry Minister Watanabe. They acknowledged an uneasiness in Japanese political and business circles about the increasing trend to preferential trade arrangements. Prime Minister Miyazawa expressed the personal view that an open and non-discriminatory multilateral trading system could be maintained despite these developments. He made clear his Government's deep commitment to a cooperative relationship with the United States and its support for an early and successful outcome of the Uruguay Round.

In underlining the importance of the bilateral trade relationship with MITI Minister Watanabe, I said that Australia would not be party to any trade arrangement which was directed against Japan. This commitment was reciprocated by his assurance that Japan would conduct its trade on a commercial basis without discrimination against Australia's interests in any arrangements with third countries. He reiterated this undertaking in the particular case of Australia's exports of automobile parts to Japan.

In discussing the outlook for the Uruguay Round, I urged Japan not to hold back on the rice tariffication issue because otherwise it ran the risk of being portrayed by others as a final obstacle to a settlement on agriculture. The Japanese Government acknowledged the responsibility it faced.

My discussions with Japanese Ministers also covered the need for expanded bilateral air services to cater for the expected increase in tourist traffic, MITI's support for Australia's trade promotion in Japanese regional centres, and Japanese involvement in the MFP project in Adelaide. In a general discussion of defence relations, I confirmed the Government's satisfaction with the current moderate level of activity, which includes high-level visits and dialogue on strategic issues.

The Government attaches considerable importance to the Asia-Pacific economic cooperation or APEC process as an essential mechanism for promoting open regionalism. I explained to Prime Minister Miyazawa the thinking behind my proposal for establishing over the medium term a process for periodic heads of government meetings based on APEC membership. Such meetings would add political weight and status to the APEC process. They would fill a significant gap in institutional arrangements in the region, enabling leaders to consult together in a way which has become familiar in European and trans-Atlantic relations. I was encouraged by a marked firming of Japanese support for the proposal. Prime Minister Miyazawa welcomed the initiative and agreed that the idea should be pursued further in consultation with other members of the region. Former Prime Minister Takeshita also firmly supported the proposal.

A special feature of the visit was my agreement with Prime Minister Miyazawa to issue a joint statement setting out for the public record an account of the regional perspectives which figured prominently in our discussions. The statement demonstrates convincingly the extent of parallel interests we share with Japan in regional strategic and economic issues and the potential we have for working together productively in the region. It also makes clear that the cooperative relationship we aim to pursue with Japan is by no means an exclusive one. Rather, it is directed towards broad-based cooperation with other countries in the Asia-Pacific region, including especially the United States. I now table the joint statement for reference by honourable members.

My program in Tokyo included an audience with the Emperor and Empress of Japan. On behalf of the Australian Government, I invited Their Majesties to visit Australia whenever mutually agreeable to the two governments. The invitation was warmly received, but because of prior consideration of other possible overseas visits it may be some time before the visit takes place. I am sure that an official visit to Australia by the Emperor and Empress will be welcomed by the vast majority of Australians.

My visit to Japan included substantial contact with senior Japanese business and financial leaders and with the Japanese media. I impressed on these audiences the progress that has been achieved in making the Australian economy more competitive and internationally oriented and the commitment of the Australian Government, private sector and wider community to strengthening Australia's relations with the Asia-Pacific region. These contacts were very useful in registering with Japanese opinion leaders the changing nature and focus of Australia.
Following my program in Tokyo, I made the first visit by an Australian Prime Minister to Nagoya, Japan's fourth largest city and the centre of a large industrial and trading region.

SPEECH.PARA: I took part in public ceremonies to mark the opening of an Australian consulate in Nagoya. This is one of four new consulates we are opening this year in Japan to strengthen our trade promotion in regional centres.

PARA.TAB: I also visited the headquarters of the Toyota Motor Corporation and inspected technologically advanced production processes at its Motomachi plant, which will serve as the parent plant for the new Toyota car factory at Altona in Victoria.In his welcoming address at a lunch given in my honour, the Toyota President said his Corporation's investment at Altona was predicated on the Australian Government's car industry policy persisting into the twenty-first century, and that consistent government policy and harmonious labour relations were always important to the car industry.

My visit to Singapore on 24 and 25 September reinforced the longstanding partnership between our two countries. Singapore is Australia's fourth largest export market and our largest trading partner among the ASEAN countries. Australia and Singapore maintain close defence relations, both bilaterally and under the five power defence arrangements, which also involve Malaysia, Britain and New Zealand.

My reception in Singapore was very warm. I had extensive discussions with Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong, Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew, Deputy Prime Minister and Trade and Industry Minister Brigadier-General Lee Hsien Loong, and Defence Minister Yeo Ning Hong. Prime Minister Goh said our bilateral relationship was in excellent shape and that Australia and Singapore were following similar strategies in the region. He welcomed Australia's efforts to engage more closely with Asia.

My discussions with Singapore leaders confirmed a broad range of agreement on regional issues, including the need to maintain an open trading system and support for promoting the APEC process. I congratulated the Singapore Government on its successful bid to host the APEC secretariat.

A major feature of my program in Singapore was participation in a very successful business seminar on the theme of strategic linkages between Singapore and Australian companies. The seminar was well attended by senior business representatives from both sides, including 28 very senior Australian business leaders who visited Singapore especially for the occasion. It provided an excellent opportunity for me and the Australian business people to explain the important ways in which the Australian economy is becoming more open and commercially integrated into the region.

Accompanied by Defence Minister Yeo, I visited HMAS Brisbane, one of eight Australian ships which had just participated in a large-scale maritime and air defence exercise under the five power defence arrangements. The Singapore Government made clear the value it places on defence cooperation with Australia, including our active role in the five power arrangements.

During the same trip abroad I visited Cambodia on 26 September. It was the first visit by an Australian Prime Minister since 1966, the first by a Western head of government since 1970, and the first by any head of government since the signing of the Paris Peace Accords in October last year.

My brief visit served two important purposes. I was able to underline Australia's firm support for the peace process at a time when serious difficulties have been caused by the refusal of the Khmer Rouge to participate in the cantonment and demobilisation phase. I was also able to reaffirm the Government's warm appreciation of the efforts of the Australian military and civilian personnel serving with the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia and of the important contribution by Australian aid workers serving with non-government organisations.

Other members of the House have visited Cambodia since the signing of the peace settlement. I know they will support me in saying that all these dedicated and professional men and women are earning a high reputation for Australia in Cambodia. Australia can be truly proud of its contribution towards peace and a better way of life for the Cambodian people.

I had detailed discussions with Prince Sihanouk, the UN Secretary-General's Special Representative, Mr Akashi, and the UNTAC Military Commander, Lieutenant-General Sanderson. Without underestimating the complexity and difficulty of problems which lie ahead, I was heartened by the determination of these key individuals to press ahead with UN-organised elections by around May next year, with or without participation by the Khmer Rouge. I assured them that Australia remained firm in its commitment to support a peace process whose outcome is a democratically elected government which can be recognised and supported by the international community. I said Australia wants to persevere so long as there is a responsible way forward.

I am confident that my visit to Japan, Singapore and Cambodia has put Australia in a better position to deal with the challenges we face in the region. I was pleased that my visit to Japan and Singapore generated considerable public comment about Australia's trade policy options. These are crucial issues for our country. It is important that Parliament and the public have a clear understanding of where our national interest lies. In recognition of Australia's position as a medium-sized trading nation with considerable diversity in the composition and direction of our trade, the Government attaches fundamental importance to maintaining and strengthening the open, non-discriminatory multilateral trading system based on the GATT. As part of this, we accord high priority to an early and successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations. The benefits of a multilateral agreement, which extends international trade rules to cover agriculture and services and which also strengthens the disciplines and dispute-settling procedures of GATT, are so overwhelming for a country like Australia that there is no need for me to describe them to this House.

We are also firmly committed to promote the development of APEC as an organisation which embraces the main economic linkages between the Western Pacific and North America. We also remain willing to seize trade opportunities and solve trade problems whenever and wherever they arise, whether bilaterally or plurilaterally, whether in a particular class of exports or with a particular country or group of countries. This kind of work is so constant and so detailed, so ordinary and unspectacular a part of the everyday work of our trade officials and of the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Mr Kerin) that we sometimes forget quite how much goes on. These three tasks—the GATT, APEC, and the everyday work of facilitating trade—remain at the core of our trade policy. But, as we enter this new era of uncertainty in the direction of the world trading system and in the strategic decisions of the major trading economies, I wish to describe the Government's approach in deciding emerging trade policy issues.

For better or worse, the Uruguay Round is coming to an end. Whatever the outcome, this will free the energies of trade policy makers and make clear the internationally agreed benchmarks upon which bilateral and regional trade enhancement can be created. If the Round fails, there will remain a vast agenda of reform in agriculture and services trade which should be addressed by some other means. Even if the Round succeeds in one form or another, there will remain plenty of room for further agreements which improve on its outcomes. As I said at the beginning of this statement, the trend towards regional, subregional and bilateral trade arrangements will probably strengthen. The European Community will certainly spread eastwards, even if there is now some doubt about the pace of deepening integration between the existing members.

NAFTA has now been signed by the governments of Canada, the United States and Mexico, and we expect that in one form or another it will be approved by the US Congress next year. We expect further links will be established between the United States and various Latin American countries. In our own region, APEC has been institutionalised with the creation of a secretariat in Singapore, while the ASEAN countries are now moving to establish their own free trade agreement. There is plenty of evidence of increased regionalism in trade institutions. There is also evidence of increased regionalism in trade patterns. Between 1970 and 1991 trade between Western European countries grew from 66 to 72 per cent of their total trade, and that between the APEC countries grew from 54 to 65 per cent of their total. So the end of the Uruguay Round is coming at the same time as Australia is changing profoundly and as regionalism becomes more important, and it is also at a time of new uncertainty over the trade strategy of the world's biggest economy, the United States.

In his recent Detroit speech, President Bush raised the possibility of negotiating trade arrangements with individual countries, including some in Eastern Europe and some in the Pacific. In the Pacific he instanced Australia, the ASEAN countries and Korea. No formal proposal has been put to Australia, but the issue is of such importance to our trading future that we cannot wait its full development before we make our own views known. Our overriding objective is to do all we can to preserve and enhance a trading environment in which our major markets remain as open to us as possible and these markets remain open to each other. We must never lose sight of the fact that most of our trade, and the fastest growing part of our trade, is now with other countries in the Western Pacific. We must also not lose sight of the fact that many of these countries are highly dependent on the US market. Finally, we must not lose sight of the fact that many of our trade partners are also our trade competitors in third country markets. Those considerations will guide us in what may well be a fluid and fast-changing external environment over the next few years.

As to the institutional forms and arrangements into which we may be prepared to enter, we are open-minded. We certainly do not rule out bilateral agreements or plurilateral agreements. Indeed, we may well initiate them, and we are of course a member of a strong bilateral arrangement with New Zealand. But some bilateral agreements are better than others, and some may deliver few bilateral trade benefits while potentially incurring substantial trade costs. The Government welcomed President Bush's Detroit speech in the sense that it demonstrated an interest in further promoting trade liberalisation in the Pacific area. The Opposition made an enthusiastic embrace of a preferential bilateral agreement with the United States despite having a week earlier labelled the United States as Australia's number one trade enemy. The Government's approach is more calibrated. We have reservations about the specific mechanism of a network of bilateral preferential trade agreements centred on the United States.

The difficulty for Australia works at several levels. First, the Government would want to consider seriously any offer of a bilateral agreement with the United States which would reduce import constraints on those items of most concern to us—particularly beef, dairy products, sugar and steel. But experience suggests that such concessions would be unlikely because of congressional attitudes and other domestic pressures in the United States. Secondly, the perception in East Asia of any move by Australia and the United States to conclude a bilateral trade agreement would vary greatly depending on whether it was seen as part of a broader, even-handed approach throughout the region, or whether it was seen as part of a strategy to put pressure on the North Asian economies, particularly Japan. In the latter case, Australia would be seen as turning our back on East Asia despite the fact that it accounts for almost six times more of our exports than the United States. Thirdly, while we can understand why some Americans advocate bilateral trade arrangements on a hub and spokes model as a way of improving US trade access, the countries at the ends of the spokes may find that this approach does not help trade between them.

A report on regional trade agreements prepared for the Government earlier this year by Professor Richard Snape and others argues convincingly that a hub and spokes system is a relatively unattractive option for trade liberalisation. These considerations were reflected in my statements in Tokyo about trade policy. As mentioned already, I told the Japanese Government that Australia would not be party to a trade arrangement which was directed against Japan. This commitment reflects a clear-sighted view of Australia's national interest.

It goes without saying that the Government attaches great weight to our relationship with the United States. Australia and all other trading nations have benefited enormously over the years from the enlightened leadership the United States has demonstrated in helping to maintain an open and non-discriminatory multilateral trading system. The Australia-US defence alliance remains of fundamental importance in the post-Cold War period. Our bilateral economic relations are of great value to both sides. As made clear in the joint statement issued with Japan, the Government believes that US strategic and economic engagement is of fundamental importance to the peace and prosperity of the Western Pacific. For this very reason we have promoted the APEC concept, which embraces both the Western Pacific and the United States, and have queried other regional concepts which omit the United States. An important objective of Australian policy is to avoid so far as we can situations where we have to choose between relations with the United States and relations with East Asia. We also want to do whatever we can to encourage cooperative relations between the two.

The Government certainly does not rule out Australian membership of regional trading arrangements. APEC is already evolving into a regional trade arrangement with a useful agenda of trade liberalising measures. If thinking and practice in the region evolves towards the idea of a trade pact, we would very much prefer that it be APEC-wide, and of course that it did not raise barriers or hinder trade between members and non-members. We appreciate that such an outcome will not be achieved easily and that, in the meantime, there may be proposals for plurilateral arrangements between subsets of the APEC membership. Australia stands ready to consider on its merits possible membership of any such arrangements that may evolve.

As I said in Tokyo, we do not think a Western Pacific trade area is a preferred arrangement, but we would certainly seek to join one if the trade policy decisions of the major players left us no better choice. So we remain open to forms and arrangements, but we do think there are substantial disadvantages for ourselves and for the entire region if the United States is encouraged to go down the path of seeking bilateral preferential arrangements.

Finally, an important principle which will guide Australian policy is that we very much want to avoid being party to a process which has the effect of dividing the Pacific into trade allies of the United States and trade allies of Japan. Working forward from the understandings reached during my recent Asian visit, these are the sorts of considerations that need to be weighed carefully in defining new Australian positions in this important policy area. Some of his most important statements were made on a bullet train, not in the context of any formal remarks, which must just stagger people as to what this bloke is on about.

As I say, he misjudged sadly the American reaction. I think it is important at the start of my remarks to look at some of this reaction. The initial reaction to his statements about the United States and taking the side of Japan was reported in one newspaper at the time pretty much to the effect that it was not going to really comment on this because it seemed to have been made for domestic political reasons—even Americans could see it. But, as time went on and he repeated his statements, not only in Japan but also in other parts of the region, the irritation obviously grew.

We saw statements by Frank Lavin, the US Deputy Secretary of Commerce in East Asia; we have seen a couple of major press reports by Gregory Hywood, an Australian who has established an outstanding reputation for commenting on US events and international events from the United States; and we have also seen some comments by Robert Zoellick, the United States Deputy Secretary of State who, in one AAP report, was reported:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to have reacted swiftly and angrily to the Australian Embassy in Washington after comments by Prime Minister Paul Keating accusing the United States of manipulating world trade.

The Prime Minister did not just stop and take the side of Japan; he actually went on the attack against the United States and accused it of manipulating world trade. This report goes on to say that Zoellick:
. . . was surprised at the remarks made by Mr Keating.

It emphasises the irritation of the White House and contrasts that with the earlier reports—as I say, that the comments were made in the context of domestic political debate. The AAP report says that Mr Zoellick:

..was amazed at Mr Keating's reaction, which came in response to a trade policy election speech in Detroit by President George Bush in which he left the door open for Australia to join in a free-trade deal with the United States.

Where are Australia's best interests when the President of the United States specifically mentions us as a possibility for a free trade arrangement as part of a network of free trade arrangements? Where are Australia's national interests when the Prime Minister goes out and accuses the President of manipulating world trade?

PARA.TAB: We cannot, in our economic circumstances, with nearly $200 billion worth of international debt, afford to look a gift horse in the mouth anywhere—the United States, Asia, Japan or anywhere else. But our Prime Minister seems capable of that. No wonder the Americans were amazed at his reaction. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The inclusion of Australia was the result of a prompting by Mr Zoellick, who has been active in persuading former Secretary of State, James Baker, now the White House Chief of Staff, of the worth of extending free-trade agreements to the Pacific.
This was a high level initiative in favour of us, an alliance partner, and he kicks them in the teeth. The report states:
The US had expected a favourable reaction—
Why would it not? It singled us out of a host of possibilities—
to the Detroit package, feeling it was doing Australia a favour showing sensitivity to Australian needs.

So he was kicked in the teeth. Why not make the point in deliberate style? One source described Mr Zoellick's view as, `What the hell are you guys up to?', after he heard of Mr Keating's remarks. The report goes on, emphasising how `the Americans were irritated that the offer was not taken up as seriously as it was intended'.

PARA.TAB: This is pretty damaging stuff. This is by a Prime Minister who claims to understand the best interests of Australian trade policy. The report goes on to refer to the proceedings of a conference in Austin, Texas, on the North American Free Trade Agreement, where speakers were referring to the post- and pre-bullet train policy of Australia. No wonder the Prime Minister was in here trying to save a bit of face and extend the olive branch to the Americans in response to some of the things that he has said in recent days. It is important to look at some of Hywood's comments. In the Australian Financial Review of 9 October he emphasised:

SPEECH.PARA: Before Canberra even knew the details of the Bush proposal—which are not yet clear—it rejected out of hand—
before it even knew the details, the Prime Minister rejected out of hand—
the idea of a bilateral FTA, the only other game in town.

PARA.TAB: It is a short-sighted strategy and inconsistent with the flexible trade policy Australia needs as it enters a particularly demanding era.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister was not short on description of this particularly demanding era, but he did not recognise what it meant in terms of Australia's economic interests and the sort of policy response he should have put in place. In another Hywood comment which refers specifically to the Prime Minister's outbursts, he says:

His outbursts against the United States in Japan a fortnight ago have caused genuine anger in the White House, particularly among the architects of Bush's new trade strategy, the former Secretary of State, now Chief of Staff, Mr James Baker, and his Deputy, Mr Robert Zoellick.

He goes on to tell how the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) was sent in to try to smooth things over in a subsequent visit to the United States. He is not the person one would send in to smooth anything over! His most outstanding success while being Minister for Foreign Affairs in this Government is that he managed to get both black and white Africa offside on the same day, but he was sent in to smooth things over. In he went to smooth things over and, as Hywood says, `Needless to say, there was no meeting of minds'. One of them started at a distinct disadvantage, for a start.

PARA.TAB: But Hywood makes a very important point—that these comments reflect what is perhaps the deepest rift in US-Australian relations in a generation. That is what the Prime Minister did. In Japan, for the sake of short term political gain back here, he brought about the deepest rift in US-Australian relations in a generation. Strategic allies for 50 years, the United States and Australia, have now very different views. Hywood goes on to demonstrate some of those views and talks about the simplistic notion of the Prime Minister of fostering GATT first: if GATT fails, go to APEC; and, if APEC fails, go to a bilateral deal. In the most damning comment, he referred to the US view of all this. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The US takes the view that you take trade liberalisation where you can get it.

If the US is prepared to take it where they can get it, why are we not prepared to take it where we can get it? What was this Japanese trip all about? It was an absolutely ridiculous situation where a Prime Minister sacrificed a longstanding trade relationship and broader alliance, and put it at risk for the sake of scoring short term political points back here at home. He shows no sense of understanding what is in Australia's best interests. He has actually brought about a whole new sense of dependence for Australia. He is the one who talks about wanting to build an independent Australia! He would not run the economic policies he runs, which make us incredibly dependent on Japan, and he would not take the sort of attitude he took in Japan, if he had a clearly independent, self-confident understanding of the nature of Australia today and our possibilities in the world.

PARA.TAB: The other distinguishing feature of today's statement is very important. It is the extent of the policy back flips evidenced in the statement: it is an absolute classic. The reason it is this way, I believe—and I can stand corrected by the Prime Minister—is that he set out months ago to make trade a major initiative. He was going to go to the area and use this Asia-Pacific debate, latterly adopted as his own, to try to neutralise the ground we had made in arguing about the future of Australia being in the Asia-Pacific region. I reckon he set out actually to make a mark. But he did not count on our making a whole series of statements in speeches and in other contexts over a much longer period which, in effect, left him nowhere to go.

The Prime Minister does not think about the economics; he does not think about what is in Australia's best interests. He just thinks about how he can score a cheap political point. If I am out there taking the ground from under him he has nowhere to go. So he belts us, and everything we say. As he belts us, he cuts off his options. Honourable members might remember the Press Club performance of the Prime Minister a couple of days before he went away where he spent the whole of his time attacking the Opposition. I reckon that originally that Press Club performance was going to be devoted to a statement on trade strategy. But he could not do it, so he made a fool of himself trying to pretend that he had changed his mind on the goods and services tax. He was played on a break on this issue. He started behind. Then he went off to Tokyo and had to bring a touch of excitement, a touch of verve with all this stuff he says he is going to bring in. He went there to try to carve out a niche for himself.

In the process, he set up a whole lot of straw men, a whole lot of phoney choices about Australia's position in relation to Japan and the United States—choices that nobody else in the region has even contemplated, because they do not exist: these choices do not have to be made. But he set them up and tried to make history on trade policy in Tokyo by playing domestic politics on the issue.

Just look at the way he has flip-flopped in this statement today compared with some of the early statements in relation to our trade policy. Let us take one example, the Bush initiative to extend the free trade arrangement from the United States on a network basis to other parts of the Asia-Pacific region. When it first came out he rushed out with a press release which said:

SPEECH.PARA: President Bush's announcement of his goal to work for a strategic network of free trade agreements, including with nations of the Pacific, is a welcomed signal that the United States recognises the need to take part in building more liberal trading arrangements in the Pacific area.

A similar comment was made by a lot of people, including us, because it was a very important signal. I said at the time that I thought it might be one of the most significant statements ever made on international trade. He greeted it in similar terms; he was not going to be outdone by us. By the time he got to Tokyo he had taken a somewhat different view. It is instructive to look at some of the newspaper reports, which were mostly filed by those journalists who remain totally objective while they travel with him and totally uninfluenced, of course, by anything he says in the briefing he might provide—anywhere from on a bullet train to in a bar. They just report it as they see it, so I assume it is accurate. `The PM attacks US again on trade' says Geoff Kitney. The article states:

"The Prime Minister, Mr Keating, sharpened his criticism of the United States trade policies yesterday as Australia and Japan moved to establish a task force to discuss a new co-ordinated approach to trade and strategic issues. Mr Keating accused the United States of a loss of confidence in its position in world trade of seeking to manipulate trade relationships. He did not believe that the positions outlined in Tokyo would upset the United States".
He went on:
"Now they are less confident—
that is, the United States—

about their industry and about their competitiveness and about their research and development base, they are going for things which I think don't let the US necessarily excel or see the US in its best light.

Here is a man who has made a clear-cut assessment of the United States: it has lost its confidence and lost its way. `PM pledges loyalty to Tokyo' is the heading in the Australian by Richard McGregor. `PM puts Japan First'—that would have gone down well—from Geoff Kitney in Tokyo. `PM sides with Japan on trade' was the heading from Peter Hartcher in Tokyo. `PM rejects Bush trade plan' was another heading. Look, the headlines are getting bigger. Another one was `Keating attacks the United States on trade'. Here is a killer: `Japan, Keating to fight trade giant' from the understated Peter Rees of the West Australian; yes, he is always objective.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister took a completely different position from the initial reaction he gave in Canberra when that Bush statement was originally released. He went further in Singapore. He deliberately misrepresented the Bush initiative by saying—this was not just in Japan; he sustained it then through the rest of the Asia-Pacific region:

SPEECH.PARA: The extension of NAFTA might well lead the US into thinking it could sustain its economic weight merely through involvement in its own hemisphere to the neglect of this region.
So there he is—one day almost a love affair, saying it is a great trade initiative, and the next, bucket, bucket, bucket of the type that we see here in the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: What have we seen today? He has had to recover a bit of that lost ground. The reaction of the United States was too strong so we have had a third back flip in as many weeks by the Prime Minister. In today's statement he recognises the interaction between Asian and American trade. He recognises the fluid and fast changing external environment—two good reasons why he has to change his mind. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: As to institutional forms and arrangements into which we may be prepared to enter,—
wait for this—
we are open minded.
It is a bit different from the bucket that they copped in Tokyo. This is the same man who condemned NAFTA so instinctively when he was overseas. He went on to say:
We certainly do not rule out bilateral agreements, . . .

Well, a lot of his remarks earlier clearly ruled them out. He spelled out a kind of bilateral agreement with the US that would be in Australia's interests. Hang on; he has gone further; he has decided in today's speech to actually spell out what it ought to look like. He said:
It goes without saying that the Government attaches great weight to our relationship with the United States.

That is classic stuff. He is doing two things: firstly trying to recover ground vis-a-vis the United States and the unexpectedly strong reaction that his statements brought from Washington and the White House and, secondly, trying to neutralise ground with us.

PARA.TAB: It is instructive that I took his speech and picked out three or four of those sentences and paragraphs to see whether I could find in them any of the things that we had been saying. We have the habit of hearing our own words coming back to us from over the table from him after a while when he decides to neutralise his remarks. I will just give a couple of examples.
An Opposition member—Plagiarism.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say plagiarism. Come on; give him a break! The man has some principles. I do not know where, but he has got them somewhere.
—That is it: do anything, say anything. On page 10 of this statement he said:

SPEECH.PARA: As I said at the beginning of this statement, the trend towards regional, subregional and bilateral trade arrangements will probably strengthen.
This is the first time he has said that. I go back to a speech I made on 15 July and I see that in my third point I said:
. . . Australia needs to respond creatively to the trend in favour of co-operative economic, regionalism and sub-regionalism. We can do this by making APEC more than a debating society—
it sounds similar to me to what he said today—
. . . by giving it some specific targets and deadlines, by involving the private sector more explicitly and by encouraging APEC's development as a GATT consistent free trade area.
So there is one piece of evidence. I also went on in that speech to say:
. . . we also need to assess objectively the prospects for Australia negotiating GATT consistent free trade agreement in goods and services with particular regional countries or groups of countries—
this was back in July of this year—
. . . to the extent that they would advance Australia's national interests in the wider region, such agreements should be actively pursued.
I have heard it all before; we said it several months ago and it comes back to us. Here is another example in today's speech:
We must not lose sight of the fact that many of these countries are highly dependent on the US market.

Let us remember that he was creating this phoney choice: if we are going to the US we are going to jettison Asia. We went out to try to argue that that was not the case; that Asians are actually capable of chewing gum and changing feet at the same time; that they can deal with the US, with Japan, with themselves and with Europe. That statement is reflected in one I made in a press release back on 27 September, commenting on some of the Prime Minister's remarks:

The fact is that the Asia-Pacific countries have rapidly expanded their exports into North America, and North American exports into Asia have grown dramatically. The key question for the Prime Minister is whether he believes that ASEAN countries will somehow be turning their backs on Asia if they decide to pursue President Bush's proposal for free trade agreements.
Two out of two already! I go to another one that he puts down here:
We certainly do not rule out bilateral agreements, or plurilateral agreements.

That sits at odds with his attack in a similar statement that I have already read. It is interesting that, when I talked about a bilateral arrangement, NAFTA, he called that stunt of a Sunday afternoon press conference. Do honourable members remember that? What did he say? He said:
Dr Hewson is attempting to throw our lot, Australia's lot, in with a country, the United States, which doesn't want us.
He said that I was naive and primitive. Well, if it fitted then, what is he today?

TALK.START.PARA: —Naive.

—Yes, naive and primitive. It is unbelievable. Of course, his fourth one today is an absolute gem, too. We may as well put them all on the record to make him happy. I am sure he is sitting back there now just enjoying this no end. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: An important objective of Australian policy is to avoid so far as we can, situations where we have to choose between relations with the United States and relations with East Asia.

So we have to choose; we have to avoid situations where we have to choose. He spent his entire time while he was away talking about all these jolly choices that we have to make as a nation. As I said in a press release back on 25 September:
. . . his main purpose was to present some kind of historic choice for Australian trade policy, in deciding between the United States and Japan.

The choice is a phoney one. No other leader in the Asia-Pacific region is arguing the case for such a choice at this time. The only reason the Prime Minister decided to promote it was his determination to use international issues for whatever short term domestic political purpose he thinks it can serve. The fact of life is that Australia must pursue all its trade options—in Asia, in Europe, in the Americas and wherever else. To talk any other way is at best misguided and at worst mischievous.

PARA.TAB: That is a clear-cut statement of our position. We have had a consistent position all the way on this. All we have seen from the Prime Minister is a blatant attempt to manipulate public opinion in Australia. He stands condemned today. He has no trade policy. He has a record of three back flips in as many weeks. He stands condemned, too, for that stunt he pulled at the Toyota car plant. I do not think poor old Dr Toyoda knew what was coming. He had no idea of the spin that was going to be put on his fairly clear-cut and straightforward remarks—the spin that would be put on his remarks back here in the domestic political debate. That certainly is not being echoed in recent statements from Toyota in Australia, which has not threatened to withdraw its investment under us at all, despite what the Prime Minister said.

My final remarks relate to some of the points that the Prime Minister made in relation to Cambodia. We welcome the fact that, as part of his recent overseas trip, the Prime Minister actually visited Australian troops serving in the UN force in Cambodia. Australian service personnel are doing, without qualification, a magnificent job under what are very difficult circumstances in Cambodia. They are serving in the highest traditions of the Australian Defence Force and they deserve a visit by an Australian Prime Minister. We are glad that they have now had one. The whole Cambodian peace process has now reached a critical stage. Events in Cambodia have moved a long way since the Government announced the deployment of Australian forces—an announcement which the Opposition supported and which we continue to support.

At the time of that announcement, the Government undertook to keep the Parliament and the Opposition fully informed of the changing circumstances concerning the Australian deployment. The reality is that circumstances have changed, and changed dramatically, in relation to the comprehensiveness of the peace process and in particular to the role of the Khmer Rouge. We believe that there is an urgent need for the Prime Minister to make a full and detailed statement to the Parliament about the changes on the ground in Cambodia, the changes to the UN peace process and the changing role of Australian forces in Cambodia.
