TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the seventh and eighth reports of the Committee for 1992 relating to Defence Logistics Redevelopment Project—Air Force aspects, and office construction at the corner of Adelaide and Creek Streets, Brisbane.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Committee's seventh report for 1992, which I have just tabled, concerns the Air Force aspects of the defence logistics redevelopment project, DLRP, which involves the implementation of a rationalised and centralised strategy of wholesale storage and distribution for the Australian Defence Force. The Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre, the second major component of the DLRP, will be the subject of a separate report from the Committee later in these sittings.

PARA.TAB: This report concerns the provision of facilities required by the RAAF to implement the relocation to forward bases of weapons systems spares as well as the rationalisation of associated property holdings. The Air Force aspects of the DLRP will allow the disposal of Defence property at Tottenham in Victoria, Toowoomba in Queensland, and Regents Park in New South Wales. The estimated cost of the proposed works is $25m. The proceeds from the sale of the properties will fund the construction of the new and enhanced facilities to be provided. The Committee's report on the Air Force aspects recommends that the works should proceed.

The report concludes that the scope of the enhancement of warehouses at seven RAAF bases can be justified on the basis of improved efficiencies and increased effectiveness resulting from the storage of weapons system spares in them. The seven operational bases are Williamtown, Edinburgh, East Sale, Amberley, Richmond, Townsville and Pearce.

The Committee also examined the future uses of RAAF storage facilities at Regents Park and concluded that warehouse 40, located there, is a valuable asset and should be retained by Defence as part of the National Storage and Distribution Centre. The land not required by Defence will be sold off. The Committee has recommended that Defence should continue discussions with Auburn Municipal Council and other planning authorities to ensure that the land which Defence proposes to sell will be used for purposes compatible with other adjacent land uses, including medium density housing.

The proposal examined by the Committee involves the relocation of No. 1 Operational Support Unit to Townsville, and the Committee concluded that this will result in improved efficiencies and response times. Townsville is the home base of the operational deployment force, and the scope of the work can be justified on the basis of operational improvements which will result in having the two units in close proximity.

The Committee's inquiry into the DNSDC and the Air Force aspects of DLRP focused in part on the fire protection measures to be provided. The Committee was advised that all upgrading of existing facilities will, as is economically cost effective, comply with the fire safety requirements of the Building Code of Australia and the Defence Manual of Fire Protection Engineering. Some fire safety standards required are more stringent than the BCA because they address the very pertinent issue of strategic risk. The Committee has nevertheless recommended that Defence should provide the Commonwealth Fire Board with details of the fire protection measures for comment.

The property implications of the proposal have considerable ramifications, not only in terms of asset sales but also in terms of job redundancies which will result from the closure of the stores depots. The Committee has concluded that the successful completion of the DLRP is dependent on the proceeds from the sale of surplus properties, funding construction, or refurbishment of warehouses and associated facilities. The Committee, therefore, recommended that Defence should ensure that optimal prices are obtained from land sales.

In relation to redundancies which will result, Defence advised the Committee that the recruitment of staff for the depots has ceased. This will provide scope for individuals to be retrained or redeployed where possible. However, Defence did acknowledge that there will be some people for whom it will not be possible to find current positions.

The Committee's eighth report for 1992 relates to the construction of a Commonwealth office building on the corner of Adelaide and Creek Streets in Brisbane. The 25-storey building will accommodate 25,000 square metres of office space and four basement levels. The building, which will be known as Terrica Place, named after the 1920 building it replaces, will primarily accommodate the Australian Taxation Office.

The Australian Taxation Office is committed to 16,000 square metres of the building, while the balance of the office space will be leased to other agencies and the ground level retail areas will be let as shops. In line with the fully commercialised nature of the office estate, all tenants will pay market based rents and will be required to enter into long term leases with Australian Estate Management. The Australian Taxation Office has agreed to a 10-year lease term with two five-year options thereafter.

Terrica Place will be built on a portion of a Commonwealth owned site, adjacent to the historic Anzac Square precinct, on which there are already two government buildings. The major one is block A of some 17 storeys built in 1972 and the other is block B of some 7 storeys built in 1934. Block B is listed on the Register of the National Estate. In addition to ensuring the preservation of block B, this development will integrate the three buildings into a single complex around a landscaped plaza. The design of the new building meets the requirements of the Australian Heritage Commission.

The construction of this building will enable the Australian Taxation Office to locate its Brisbane central business district activity in the one building and will greatly enhance administrative efficiency. The completion of the building will increase the proportion of Commonwealth owned office space in Brisbane from 27 per cent to 42 per cent. The project will protect the Commonwealth from the strong rent increase expected in Brisbane at the time of completion of this project.

The Committee is satisfied, on the basis of confidential information provided to it, that the project is the most cost-effective means of meeting the Commonwealth's accommodation requirements in the Brisbane central business district. The estimated out-turn cost of the project is $82m—not cheap—although the Committee was advised by Australian Estate Management that in the current extremely competitive tendering market it is confident of receiving a tender price below that figure. I commend the reports to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—We support the defence logistics redevelopment projects mentioned in the Public Works Committee report, but the Opposition reserves the right in future to reassess its position in relation to the whole area of defence and this sort of rationalisation. I note that it is proposed to undertake warehouse enhancements at a number of RAAF bases—this particular report relates only to the RAAF, of course. Those programs are at Williamtown, Edinburgh, East Sale, Amberley, Richmond, Townsville and Pearce. The Committee reported that there was a need for the RAAF to improve its regional warehousing facilities. The funds to be spent—some $25m—will in part come from the sale of the other properties.

PARA.TAB: The report went on to note that many of the older properties, some located at Toowoomba, Tottenham, Dubbo and those sorts of areas, were old depots, some dating back to World War II. I can appreciate that. In fact, I find what has happened most unfortunate. Many of the buildings that we have in the defence area do not suit the modern equipment that we have today. They do not provide dust free environments and those sorts of things—including, of course, adequate working facilities for certain defence staff. So I certainly support the provision of these new and modern facilities for what is a new and modern defence force in Australia which needs to be appropriately supplied and equipped. As I mentioned, we support the report, but there are aspects of this matter still before the PWC which we reserve the right in government to review.

The Committee's second report concerns the office construction at the corner of Adelaide and Creek Streets, Brisbane. I note that more than half the 150,000 square metres of vacant office space currently available in the Brisbane CBD is contained in a handful of prime buildings which would not be acceptable to the Commonwealth for its purposes. As I just mentioned, the report pointed out that there are currently 150,000 square metres of vacant office floor space in the Brisbane CBD, and that rings true with other capital cities. Commonwealth departments currently occupy 176,000 square metres of office space in the Brisbane CBD and, of this, only 47,000 square metres, or 27 per cent, is owned by the Commonwealth.

On a lighter note, this building will provide 25,000 square metres of office space but it is going to provide 210 car parking bays. I wonder how much the Tax Office is going to have to pay back to itself and the Government in fringe benefit taxes on car parking spaces. We support the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Initially, I thank the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for the opportunity to make a brief submission and attend its inspection. The aspect relevant to my electorate is the Regents Park site. I am pleased with two conclusions reached by the Committee. Firstly, in relation to warehouse 40, there was at one stage a push that it be sold with the rest of the site. That was opposed by the National Union of Workers and the local officers, because—and this was the conclusion of the Committee—it is viable, it is useful and it has involved significant capital expenditure. I am pleased to say that the Committee has reached a similar view, that it should not be sold with the rest of the site. This particular Air Force base is a significant employer, both in my electorate and that of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and the continued existence of that part of the operation will guarantee at least some jobs.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I note that the Committee urges that there be some consultation between the Auburn Council and the Department. In recent years the Fahey State Government and its predecessor have at last started to tackle the problem of urban consolidation in Sydney. As I say, this has been ignored by governments of both political stripes. Unfortunately, in their decision to tackle that problem we see a class bias. Virtually all of the suggested regions for increased consolidation happen to be in working class western Sydney electorates. In actual fact, of about 30 railways they have chosen, one or two were on the North Shore. That is a massive indication of their bias in these matters.

At another defence site within the electorate—that is, the Merrylands reserve depot—there has been an unfortunate indication of the attitude of the State Government of New South Wales which I see this Committee repudiating. That Government decided, without consultation with the Federal Department, that it would rezone and gazette for medium density the particular property at the intersection of Woodville Road and Merrylands Road. That is typical of the degree of studied disinterest in the views of local residents and the Federal Government.

I am pleased that in this report the Committee has strongly recommended that there be consultation between the Federal Government department and the local council. That council has of course suggested that the site should be principally utilised for housing, whether medium density or whatever. I congratulate the Committee on reaching these decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I am pleased to support the recommendation of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works with respect to the new Terrica Place building to be constructed in Adelaide Street, Brisbane. It is in a central precinct; it is an ideal location for the purpose. It is also a building surrounded with some historic significance. It is adjoined by Anzac Square and the memorial in the centre of the city, and it has beside it other historic buildings owned by the Commonwealth. Most notable of those is the building between it and Anzac Square which was built in 1934. I am pleased to note that the proposals for the new Terrica Place take account of that heritage value and that the design of the new Terrica Place incorporates a facade which very properly fits in with that historical precinct of which it will form an important part. I am particularly pleased to note that the Government is meeting the requirements of the Australian Heritage Commission, and it deserves great credit for that.

PARA.TAB: The other building which is part of that precinct is the Australian Government Centre. I had the pleasure of having my electorate office located there for some 18 months or so and I am very familiar with that part of the city. It is very central. It provides easy access for the people of Brisbane, with the Central railway station literally across the road in Ann Street. The use of that site for such a building is a wise decision.

The Australian Government would now be the major building construction authority in the Brisbane city area. This new building now going ahead—a significant building of some 25 storeys—joins a number of other construction activities which have been approved by this Parliament. I wish to mention a couple of those, if I may. The new Federal Court building, which is now nearing completion at North Quay, is a major building and a beautiful addition to what is a lovely part of the Brisbane CBD area overlooking the river across to the south bank and the Cultural Centre. I had the pleasure of inspecting that site with the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, and was impressed by the commitment of the people involved on site and the quality of the work being done. The other major activity being undertaken by the Commonwealth, which I also wish speedy progress, is the new international airport. I will not dwell on that, but I am sure the Committee has that in mind for further consideration.

I congratulate the Committee on its report and the Government for its clear intentions to construct the new Terrica Place. It will be a fine building. It will admirably house the Australian Taxation Office. DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 12 October.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendment of the Automotive Industry Authority Act 1984

SPEECH.PARA: Part 2 of the Bill amends the Automotive Industry Authority Act 1984 to change the termination date of the Automotive Industry Authority from 31 December 1992 to 31 December 2000.

PARA.TAB: The amendment arises from the March 1991 industry statement in which the Government announced new arrangements for the automotive industry to the year 2000. As part of those arrangements the Government also announced that it would maintain an independent body for the duration of the arrangements to monitor the performance of the industry and to give advice and information to Government on the industry. The Government's decision to maintain an independent body was made on the recommendation of the Industry Commission.

The Automotive Industry Authority has built up considerable knowledge of the automotive industry and has shown itself capable of providing independent and factual advice to government. The authority is well placed to carry out the required monitoring role to the year 2000. Continuation of the existing authority will involve ongoing annual running costs of some $1.1m to cover administrative expenses and salaries and $215,000 annual property operating expenses. This level of funding is consistent with previous years' operations and agreed with the Department of Finance.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments of the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act 1905

PARA.TAB: The Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act 1905, amongst other things, makes it an offence to import or export goods to which a false trade description is applied. In the past 12 months the Australian Customs Service has reported an increasing number of interceptions of garments and footwear which contravene this legislation. As recently stated by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), this indicates a need for an increased deterrent to prevent importers playing the odds by importing falsely described goods. The penalties under the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act have not been increased since the legislation was enacted in 1905. Part 2A of the Bill will increase penalties for contravening the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act. The amendments are expected to result in an increase in revenue receipts.

Part 2B of the Bill will make a change to the Designs Act 1906 necessitated by two recent decisions of the Federal Court which have held, amongst other things, that designs for articles of uniform cross-section but of indefinite length are not registrable under the Designs Act. This has the undesired effect of invalidating many registered designs, against the spirit and policy behind the legislation. The amendment is necessarily retroactive in order to preserve the validity of current design registrations. Provisions will also be included for the protection or compensation of persons who acted in the belief that the registration of a design was invalid as a consequence of the Federal Court's decisions. The amendment will have no financial impact.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments of the National Measurement Act 1960

PARA.TAB: The National Measurement Act 1960 provides the basis for the Australian national measurement system. The objective of the Act is to ensure that measurements are made on a consistent basis throughout the nation and are compatible with measurements in other countries. The Bill will amend the National Measurement Act 1960 to make consequential provisions resulting from the enactment by State and Territory governments of the uniform trade measurement legislation, to include provisions for a broader range of legal measurements than are presently allowed for in the Act and to clarify Australia's obligations under the international convention on legal metrology and to ensure that legal measuring instruments in use in Australia comply with national and international requirements.

With the introduction of uniform trade measurement legislation, verification of measuring instruments for use for trade will be replaced to a significant extent by certification of measuring instruments by licensed personnel. As the amount of error determined for a particular measuring instrument may vary according to the test procedure adopted, and to ensure that verification, reverification and certification procedures are uniformly applied throughout Australia, the provision of test procedures in certificates of approval is necessary.

The uniform trade measurement legislation also requires that verification tolerances, which may have different values, are those permitted under the Act. A legal opinion from the Attorney-General's Department concluded that `an amount of error probably allows for the more than one set of tolerances to be specified', but recommended that the Act be amended to expressly state that opinion.

The Act and regulations currently provide for the Commission to undertake pattern approval of measuring instruments used for trade. Pattern approval aims to ensure that measuring instruments are not capable of facilitating fraud, that they will maintain their accuracy between verifications and will not be adversely affected by changes in environmental conditions.

It is estimated that goods to the value of $40 billion are traded across Commission approved equipment each year. If measuring instruments do not comply with the approved pattern, then the community may suffer loss in two ways. Firstly, the non-complying instruments might include features that facilitate fraud. Secondly, the instruments might not be able to maintain calibration and might not be recalibrated unless it is in the vendor's interest to do so. Australia could also suffer loss of export revenue from the sale of resources such as coal, wheat, wool and sugar if non-complying instruments are used.

The Act provides for penalties if instruments falsely purport to comply with an approved pattern. However, no mechanism exists for instruments to be checked for compliance. State and Territory trade measurement authorities, a Public Service Board review of the pattern approval procedures, and Commission risk analysis reports have each identified pattern compliance as an essential component in maintaining the integrity of the trade measurement system.

In 1959 Australia acceded to the international convention establishing an international organisation of legal metrology. The organisation was vested with responsibility for determining international requirements for legal measuring instruments and member states were `morally obliged to implement these decisions as far as possible'. With the globalisation of trade the convention has gained increasing importance and is in harmony with the GATT agreement on technical barriers to trade. The amendment clarifies Australia's measurement requirements under this convention and will be an essential component of mutual recognition agreements with Australia's trading partners. The Bill will extend the traceability provision of the Act to include legal measuring instruments and analytical measurements using certified reference.

The Act and regulations currently provide for the pattern approval and certification of measuring instruments used for trade. Pattern approval aims to ensure that measuring instruments will maintain their accuracy between verifications and will not be adversely affected by changes in environmental conditions. At the present time measuring instruments used for legal purposes other than trade measurement are not subject to pattern approval procedures.

The Commission has been approached by some State government authorities to provide for certification of some legal instruments to facilitate demonstration of traceability of these instruments in legal proceedings. Pattern approval to international standards would be an important prerequisite for certification of these instruments. The amendment makes provision for pattern approval, verification and certification of legal measuring instruments that may be applied as found appropriate.

Reference materials are important for a wide range of measurements in industry and government regulation. Examples would include environmental monitoring and breathalyser measurements. As many reference materials originate overseas they currently would not comply with the provisions of the Act. The amendment to provide for certification of reference materials by the National Standards Commission will overcome this deficiency in the Act. The amendments have no financial impact.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendment of the Science and Industry Research Act 1949

PARA.TAB: This Bill provides an opportunity to make a minor amendment to subsection 10B(4) of the Science and Industry Research Act 1949 relating to the office of the Chief Executive of CSIRO. The Bill brings that subsection into line with current legislative practice by providing that decisions about residual terms and conditions of appointment shall be made by the Minister rather than the Governor-General. The amendment has no financial impact.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments of the Trade Marks Act 1955

PARA.TAB: Part 5 of the Bill amends the Trade Marks Act based on recommendations of the working party to review the trademarks legislation which has recently presented its report to me. The working party's report, Recommended Changes to the Australian Trade Marks Legislation, includes a number of recommendations to increase the present penalties for selling or importing, et cetera, counterfeit goods and for forging trademarks.

In the light of serious concerns raised by industry and other parties, the Government has taken the immediate measure of amending the Trade Marks Act in this portfolio Bill so as to implement stiffer penalties for counterfeiting and forgery in line with the report's recommendations. The penalties were last increased in 1985.

This intention to take immediate action was announced by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce as part of the Government's package of initiatives to underpin the development of internationally competitive textile, clothing and footwear companies, and by me when releasing the report. The amendments are expected to result in an increase in revenue receipts. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 12 October.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.

The primary purpose of the Australian Industry Development Corporation Amendment Bill is to amend the Australian Industry Development Corporation Act 1970 to extend the Commonwealth guarantee until 30 June 1998, as announced in November last year. This Bill will also clarify issues relating to the AIDC's trading powers and reduce the size of its board. The extension of the Commonwealth guarantee to 30 June 1992 will have no net effect on revenue.

PARA.TAB: AIDC, the Corporation, is a government business enterprise which was established in the early 1970s. In 1989 the operations of the Corporation were changed: a new company, AIDC Ltd, was floated on the Australian Stock Exchange. The Corporation retains an 81 per cent interest in AIDC Ltd.

AIDC Ltd has taken over the investing operations formerly carried out by the Corporation. It operates in a commercial manner without government direction. Under a management arrangement between the Corporation and AIDC Ltd, the Corporation is the borrower on behalf of AIDC Ltd. The AIDC Act allows for AIDC borrowings to be guaranteed by the Commonwealth. At 30 June 1992 the amount of borrowings guaranteed by the Commonwealth stood at around $2.7 billion.

The AIDC Act currently provides for the Commonwealth guarantee on AIDC borrowings to expire on 30 June 1994. This Bill amends section 35 of that Act to implement the Government's decision to extend the guarantee to 30 June 1998. There is also a need to clarify the Commonwealth's obligation to AIDC's borrowings made during the operation of the Commonwealth guarantee, but which are subsequently rolled over into a further investment. These amendments ensure that the guarantee does not continue on moneys reinvested after the statutory limit on the Commonwealth guarantee has expired.

At present the board of AIDC is composed of a chairman, the chief executive of the Corporation and the secretaries of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Department of Primary Industry and Energy. At present the statutory minimum number of other directors is between four and eight.

AIDC is now basically a holding corporation with AIDC Ltd as the operating company of the group. Indeed, since 1990 AIDC has been managed by AIDC Ltd under an agreement between them. Accordingly, the requirement for a large board is no longer appropriate. It is proposed that the number of other directors who may be appointed be reduced to one.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Power of AIDC to enter into swaps and other financial transactions

PARA.TAB: A UK court ruling has called into question the power of statutory corporations to enter into certain financial arrangements such as interest rate swaps, foreign exchange agreements, forward rate agreements, options, futures, or hedge agreements. Given AIDC's role as a corporation operating in financial markets, it is important to have its powers clearly defined. These amendments make it clear that the AIDC has these powers. I commend the Bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 September, on motion by Mr Baldwin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to confine my comments to the aged care provisions of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). These provisions relate to hostel subsidies, domiciliary nursing care, private nursing home funding and resident classification reviews. The Bill also introduces what appear to be a number of minor amendments to various pieces of health legislation, necessary as a result of incorrect and sloppy drafting and legislative oversights. However, I will leave this aspect of the Bill to my colleague the shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods).

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I refer to hostel subsidies. All subsidies for financially disadvantaged persons, whom I refer to as FDPs, are to be increased by 55c a day and personal care subsidies are to be reduced by $2.65 a day for non-financially disadvantaged persons. The $2.65 a day reduction to non-FDP rates equates to the current hostel care subsidies which are payable only to financially disadvantaged persons. It is intended that at all levels of care within a hostel there will be a $3.20 a day subsidy difference between the financially disadvantaged residents and the non-financially disadvantaged residents. The rationale behind this measure is that hostels have a greater capacity to raise income from their non-FDP residents through entry contributions and variable fees, and that government subsidies will be better targeted to support those in need.

The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin), in his second reading speech, suggested that the real impact on the resident and the hostel should be minimal as the changes, in combination with forthcoming real increases in pension income through pension and rental assistance increases, largely offset each other. Aged Care Australia, the peak body representing hostels in the voluntary sector, had this response:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's decision, taken without consultation with the industry and applied retrospectively, strikes at the very heart of their social justice program.

The reduction in subsidies to non-FDP hostel residents is a cost-cutting measure by the Government which will ultimately disadvantage hostel proprietors in the voluntary sector. Higher charges are available to hostels from non-FDPs, but contracts are entered into between residents and proprietors regarding entry contributions on a monthly or annual fees basis. For many hostels, existing contracts and retirement village legislation will preclude adjustments to residents fees until either the annual review or automatic CPI adjustment, or with the permission of the resident.

PARA.TAB: Small and remote hostels that relied on their local community for capital fundraising have made commitments to their communities regarding entry contributions and differential fees. I raise the issue of the small rural and remote hostels because they will be particularly disadvantaged, especially in this time of great recession and the rural depression that is having a massive impact on those very small and isolated communities where some of these hostels are located.

This Budget measure will impact severely on the financial viability of small hostels. Aged Care Australia has pointed out that there is a case for subsidy increases for small hostels which continue to be uneconomic. It has stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately the Government is continuing to approve the construction of small stand-alone hostels despite continuing advice by us that these facilities are clearly uneconomic. This will only be overcome through the expansion of multi-purpose centres.

It seems crazy to continue to support stand-alone hostels when we could get much better utilisation of resources by supporting the multi-purpose centres. Aged Care Australia has pointed out that the so-called real increase in pensions and rent assistance of the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) is illusory.

PARA.TAB: The low consumer price index is artificially low as a guide to inflation in the aged care sector. The low CPI is due mainly to reductions in the housing component which, in turn, reflects the dramatic reduction in rates that we have seen in this nation and does not really reflect the actual CPI increase.

The fall in interest rates is of minimal benefit to the aged population, who are instead suffering because their interest income has dropped sharply. This is reflected in the growth of the number of people in receipt of age pension and part pension. Without the effect of lower interest rates, the CPI would have risen by 2 1/2 per cent from June 1991 to June 1992. Actual costs in hostels and nursing homes have risen even more than this over the past 12 months and are expected to increase even faster in the near future due to the pending award increases and increases in the occupational superannuation and superannuation levies. I wonder whether these factors were considered when drafting these amendments to this legislation.

Reducing personal care subsidies by $2.65 a day for non-financially disadvantaged persons is estimated to save the Government in excess of $9m in 1993-94. Aged Care Australia said that as a result of the estimated savings:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government clearly wants the non-FDP resident to pick up the cost of both generating the Budget cost saving of over $9m per annum and the increased subsidy of financially disadvantaged person residents.

Interest income for non-FDP residents has dropped sharply as a result of falling interest rates and many financially disadvantaged persons do not have the capacity to pay the increased fees. Furthermore, the existing definition of `financially disadvantaged person' does not give a good guide to the capacity of a hostel resident to pay increased fees.

PARA.TAB: Many non-financially disadvantaged persons now have the full age pension as their sole source of income because they may have divested or spent their assets. Being a non-financially disadvantaged person is no measure of increased capacity to pay, especially as much of the resident's assets are used for the increasingly large entry contribution necessary to fund the initial capital cost. Aged Care Australia therefore recommends that the definition of financially disadvantaged person for the purpose of recurrent funding in hostels be changed to a basis of the resident being in receipt of a full single age pension and not owning a home.

In Aged Care Australia's detailed submission to the Minister the following recommendations were also made: firstly, coinciding with the 55c increase in the FDP subsidies, the personal care subsidy for non-financially disadvantaged persons should be reduced by $1.45. This represents 55c offset for the FDP increase and 85c of the $1 per week non-indexed pension increase due to be introduced at the end of January 1993.

Secondly, the remaining $1.20 of the personal care subsidy cut should be introduced following a national review of hostel operating costs. This review is to include examining the capacity of hostels to reduce operating costs without impairing quality of care and to increase fees to non-financially disadvantaged residents.

Finally, on the topic of hostel subsides, I must make mention of the difficulties and complexities involved in hostel management. The 1991 Budget introduced three levels of personal subsidies targeted to the different care needs of residents in hostels: personal care high, personal care intermediate, and personal care low. In addition, there is a hostel care subsidy which is payable for residents who do not require personal care.

With the introduction of changes of hostel subsidy arrangements, instead of four levels of subsidy, there will be seven, thus creating more complex administration and budgeting and clerical activity. That will certainly impact on the hostels and, I imagine, on the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, which has to administer this Act. So much for the Government's gross hypocrisy when it made the accusation that the GST in the Fightback package will introduce more book work into people's everyday lives. This change will create more and, we believe, unnecessary book work for the hostel proprietors. The coalition parties are of the opinion that the question of hostel subsidies should be referred to a Senate legislative committee for consideration.

I turn my attention now to the resident classification reviews. The amendments to the classification review provisions for nursing home residents allow for retrospective reclassification of nursing home residents to the date of original classification. Currently, a resident is classified according to the resident classification instrument—that is, the RCI—which measures a resident's need for nursing and personal care. When validation of this assessment means a change in classification, the change takes effect from the date of validation. On this side of the House, the coalition parties have taken on board the concerns of the aged care industry regarding the retrospective reclassification of nursing home residents which can occur at any time up to the period of reassessment, which is 12 months.

The industry states that, if the secretary revokes a classification and substitutes a classification that requires a lower funding level, the nursing home proprietor, under the proposed amendment, will be required to repay the Commonwealth the difference between the funding at the reclassified level and the level of the original classification. This refund will be required even though the nursing home proprietor has already spent the money on personal care for the resident.

The National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals Inc. has raised the following concerns with regard to the reclassification. It says that residents in nursing homes are classified by directors of nursing and their staff, utilising their professional knowledge and expertise in the best interests of frail aged persons entrusted to their care. They also use the RCI guidelines for directors of nursing provided by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. These nursing staff are professionally trained to care for the frail aged and understand the levels of care required by the residents on a daily basis. Departmental officers who have no working knowledge of the residents concerned cannot properly make retrospective judgments based on paper assessments of these frail aged and a single visit, often without the individual resident being assessed.

Secondly, the proposed changes will hurt and disadvantage nursing homes financially. The RCI reviews over the last 12 months clearly show that in the vast majority of cases a resident's classification is upgraded, giving the nursing home less funding specifically for nursing staff and personal care. Directors of nursing have commented that they have grave concerns about the power given to the RCI inspectors who, through downgrading residents, could literally send a nursing home into bankruptcy overnight.

As the RCI tool is only a means of funding nursing care staff, it has no financial effect on the profits of the nursing home. All moneys forwarded to the nursing home through this funding are utilised for nursing staff. It is absolutely ridiculous that money that has been expended on staff wages should be claimed back retrospectively. The money that will be paid back will have to come from other areas, adversely affecting the standards of care received by the elderly.

I believe that the final concern raised by the National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals illustrates the callous disregard this Government has for the efforts of those dedicated nurses working in aged care hostels across the nation. In fact, the amendment has the direct result of cutting staffing levels to already cash-strapped nursing homes, further adding to the burden of Australia's huge unemployment problem. The industry's recommendation is that, as this Budget item will have no financial impact on the Commonwealth in the 1992-93 financial year, this matter should be referred to a Senate committee for further consideration. The National and Liberal parties support the industry's recommendation.

I move to the issue of domiciliary nursing care. Care to the aged and disabled is provided both at home, under the home and community care program, commonly known as the HACC program, and at institutions, principally in hostels. A number of services are provided under HACC, including home help, nursing, meals, maintenance and transport. The home and community care program aims to enable those who do not require institutional care to continue to live in their homes and remain part of the community. As part of the scheme, assistance is provided through the domiciliary and nursing care benefit, the DNCB. The DNCB is not subject to a means test, is tax free and is currently paid at the rate of $42 per fortnight.

This Bill provides an increase in the DNCB from $21 a week to $26 a week from 6 January 1993. The benefit is to be indexed annually on the basis of the CPI changes and will also be paid to carers during periods of respite care of up to 42 days per year. Whilst the increase of $5 a week in the DNCB is welcomed, the industry, carers and consumers feel that it is still woefully inadequate at $26 per week.

I move to the issue of private nursing home funding. The 1991-92 Budget introduced a system under which additional recurrent funding would be provided for a period of 10 years where a proprietor builds a new home or completely rebuilds an existing home. The Bill will implement the 1992-93 Budget decision to expand the funding available under this system. However, the funding is capped. An approval in principle system for new and rebuilt homes is created, allowing borrowing against increased recurrent funding after the home is built or rebuilt. However, it is possible that many proprietors who do not intend to rebuild their homes in the near future will, nevertheless, apply for an approval in principle just in case they change their minds or the State health authorities force them to rebuild.

There is, therefore, a risk that the available approvals in principle will be wasted. To avoid this possibility this legislative amendment allows the approval in principle to be revoked if no progress is made towards the rebuilding. The approvals in principle will then be able to be reallocated. The voluntary sector is concerned that it has been virtually excluded from the additional funding provided for new and rebuilt private nursing homes and former participating religious charitable homes.

In conclusion, whilst we will not be declining to give the Bill a second reading, the Opposition is of the opinion that certain sections of the Bill should be subject to a detailed consideration by a parliamentary committee. The Opposition supports the industry's call for the provisions relating to hostel subsidies and resident classification reviews to be referred to a Senate legislative committee for consideration. Neither of these measures was discussed with the industry, nor has there been any proper consultation as to the implementation and effect of these measures on the viability of the industry. In view of the seriously critical importance of the maintenance of existing services to the well-being of older persons residing in hostels and nursing homes, it is not good enough to simply consider that these matters are Budget

SPEECH.PARA: measures and, therefore, require automatic support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the measures incorporated in the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). This Bill facilitates measures aimed at providing assistance for aged care—an extension of this Government's proud record of support for our aged citizens.

PARA.TAB: The amendments encompass a range of issues, including the amendments to part III of the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act 1954, which are designed to increase equity with regard to hostel subsidies by providing higher subsidies for financially disadvantaged persons. The Bill amends the Health Insurance Act 1973 to close a loophole which would enable a child, in respect of whom family allowance is not being paid because of the income or assets test, to be declared a disadvantaged person and thus be issued with a health care card and receive pharmaceutical benefits at the concessional rate of patient contribution.

This Bill also amends part VAB of the National Health Act 1953. Part VAB of the National Health Act currently contains provisions allowing additional recurrent funding to be provided when a nursing home is rebuilt or when a new nursing home is built. The aim of these provisions is to improve the quality of nursing home buildings and, hence, to improve the quality of care. The nursing home industry took the view that this initiative would not efficiently meet its objective, since a proprietor could only apply for the additional funding after building the new home. The industry said that a proprietor considering rebuilding his home needed an assurance of the additional funding before construction commenced, as he would not otherwise be able to borrow the money to rebuild. The proposed amendment overcomes this problem and introduces a system of approvals in principle.

The proposed amendments of section 4 of the National Health Act will allow for Medicare benefits payable under the Health Insurance Act, for consultations by participating optometrists to private patients in a hospital or day hospital facility to be treated as domiciliary visits so as to attract Medicare benefits at the 85 per cent rate, rather than the 75 per cent rate for hospital patients.

Another change proposed in relation to the domiciliary nursing care benefit implements decisions taken by the Government in the 1992 Budget context to increase the benefit from $42 to $52 per fortnight from January 1993, to maintain its value thereafter by annual indexation, and to continue payment of the benefit for up to 42 days per calendar year during periods of respite care—a measure which will be welcomed by many affected people.

Since the Labor Government came to power in 1983, it has greatly increased the funding available to the nursing home industry. Commonwealth funding for aged care has increased significantly since 1983-84 when the funds spent per person aged 70 and over was $946. This figure has grown to $1,894 in 1991-92. In real terms, allowing for inflation, this Government is now directly spending an extra $339 per person for people in this age group.

The Government's aim has always been to assist nursing home proprietors to improve the quality of life and the quality of care for nursing home residents. We have deliberately designed strategies aimed at enabling our elderly citizens to have a choice about the kind of accommodation they want in their senior years. For many, declining health has meant that a nursing home is the only option with essential nursing care offered in these facilities. But age pensioners without assets have often faced a decision between a no frills option, while the opportunity still existed for those with the cash to enjoy extra comforts in their later years.

This Government has introduced initiatives that give people in most need increased support by way of increased subsidies to nursing homes and hostels. This is an important aspect of our social policy. I am aware that a difficult situation can still exist for many aged and frail aged people wanting to get into nursing homes or hostels, particularly with the increasing ratio of elderly people to young people in the work force who, on a year by year basis, actually provide the funds or the facilities for the senior generations. It is in this context that these initiatives must be seen as cogs in the Labor strategy to give choices to our senior citizens—one of the most valued of which is the choice to remain in one's own home when age and frailty make the help of a carer necessary. This is a situation which many people will face. It is a situation which people in this House will, at some stage, most likely be facing.

In 1984 the Federal Government initiated, in conjunction with the State governments, the now well-known home and community care program. HACC funds services which enable frail elderly people and people with disabilities who choose this option to remain living in their own homes. These services include repair or maintenance tasks, such as even changing a light bulb, replacing tap washers and garden maintenance, and also include general household support, such as help with cleaning, cooking, shopping and personal care. It is these little chores, taken for granted by many of us, that can make the difference between the ability to live at home or the necessity to move into a nursing home.

I am very pleased to have in my electorate of Lilley in Queensland a new Advocacy Centre, a service for older people which was announced recently by the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples). The HACC Advocacy Centre in Nundah, under its new title, the Older Persons Advocacy Centre, OPAS, has been expanded to provide advocacy services for residents of nursing homes and hostels, as well as frail aged people living in the community. It is important to note that, despite its name, the service caters for people of all ages with disabilities who may access the services of OPAS. I urge such people to take advantage of the service as an adjunct to the growing number of facilities fashioned specifically for them. I will address the issue of specific facilities for people with disabilities at another time. They may not, and often do not, wish to be linked with services for frail aged people.

At this stage, I will outline the services offered by OPAS. The centre fulfils two roles incorporating the HACC programs, as well as promoting the rights of people living in nursing homes and in hostels. It provides free and confidential advice so that people are assisted to make informed choices for themselves and, if necessary, advocates are available to act on behalf of their clients. The Advocacy Centre will inform people of their rights and support them when they have decided how best to address issues of particular concern to them.

I would like to commend publicly here, Wendy Skitch, the Golden Years Senior Citizens Centre and the staff at OPAS who have pulled together in a cooperative and positive manner to offer this service to residents of Brisbane. I also congratulate the Minister for establishing the Older Persons Advocacy Centre in an electorate—my electorate—which has 15 per cent of people in receipt of age pensions. It has 17 nursing homes, including Eventide, the largest in Queensland, and nine age hostels catering for over 2,000 people. HACC recognises the invaluable role of carers in enabling the majority of frail older people and people with disabilities to remain living independently in the community.

One of the most important services provided directly to carers by HACC is respite. This provides a break from the pressures and stresses of looking after their relatives which is essential to the well-being of the carer. The most commonly used form of respite under HACC is provided by day care centres. Clients can spend several hours a day, several days a week, in a day care centre where meals will be provided and activities conducted both to entertain and to give practice in maintaining skills. They are magnificent services. Alternatively, respite may be provided in the client's home for a few hours a day or even overnight. This service is vital in helping carers to go on with their task. Often carers have little time for themselves—no time for shopping, visiting friends or spending quality time with others or their own family members. I believe it is appropriate in the framework of this debate to acknowledge the measures taken by this Government to assist carers, the unsung heroes of our community.

Carers come from all walks of life and all kinds of backgrounds. They are in every street in every suburb. They include people who speak little or no English and those with special cultural traditions, including Aborigines. They are people in cities and in remote communities. They are mostly women, but there is a growing number of male carers. They can be any age. There are adult children looking after their ill or ageing parents, and elderly people looking after a partner. Many care for someone who has a disability, and a large number of parents devote their lives to the care of children with disabilities.

Within this enormous community of carers there are even more distant relatives and friends who have made the decision to take up the role of carer. Without these people the drain on the public purse to provide institutional care would be overwhelming. It is realistic to say that many other Government initiatives at all levels of government would never eventuate if taxpayers had to provide complete care for a significant portion of the community.

One of the important measures in the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is aimed at supporting carers by making changes to the domiciliary nursing care benefits. It provides financial assistance to 33,000 carers who provide invaluable 24-hour care and support for people who would otherwise probably be in a nursing home. In the recent Budget, the Government made a crucial contribution to carers as part of the $93m package. These initiatives reflected strong recognition by the Government of the immense contribution of carers to the Australian community and the important opportunity they provide to people who, without their care, might no longer be able to live at home.

Such changes, initiated by this Government, will help people such as Ann, a constituent who came into my electorate office a couple of weeks ago. Her mother is now unable to care for herself so Ann, who is now 50 and with a career, is seriously considering giving up her job and caring for her mother. I was able to tell her of the increased level of benefits that will take effect from January that will give her an income and that the income will be indexed annually to ensure that the benefit maintains its value in real terms.In addition, the benefit will continue during the periods of respite care that she can receive for her mother; that will be up to 42 days per year. In this way, there will be support for Ann while she takes a much deserved break from the continuing care task. Respite care is the service most valued by carers. The Government is providing a substantial boost in financial assistance to carers through the domiciliary nursing care benefit. This is just one example of our ongoing support of those in our community who really need it.

One of the most stressful situations facing an increased number of people in our community is that of a person close to them suffering from Alzheimer's disease or from dementia. This means a progressive decline in the sufferer's ability to cope with everyday life. There is presently no reprieve once the condition is diagnosed, although research is being undertaken into the area and it is hoped that there will soon be a breakthrough. There may be behavioural disturbances and, in the end, incontinence. Eventually the time may come when people suffering from Alzheimer's do not even recognise who is caring for them—often a child, or a spouse of decades. This brings heartbreak. This is truly a heart-wrenching lifestyle in which the costs are many but the rewards are few. Despite this, countless thousands of people continue in the caring role. These are the people who are assisted by provisions of the legislation under discussion tonight, the original Act, and the many programs put forward under HACC and other policies of this Government. They are people who are the human face of the debate, the statistics and the policy statements that we put forward in this House, and I think it is appropriate that we think of that flowthrough as we discuss the legislation.

A 1988 survey of ageing and disability estimated that about 300,000 carers live in the same house as the people they care for. There are doubtless many more who are able to live elsewhere, and many of these people do not themselves recognise that they are carers; they simply see it as their responsibility. They act from a motivation of love and would not surrender their role, but they suffer from stress and isolation, and may need assistance to maintain their caring role. This Government has recognised the needs of these diverse groups through the release of its carers policy and the assistance announced in the Budget.

The HACC program recognises that carers are absolutely essential to the proper support of the majority of frail older people and younger people with disabilities who wish to remain living independently in the community. HACC provided over $54m last year in respite services. It was money wellspent. Despite this, there remains a significant unmet demand. In order to address that demand, this Government has allocated a further $40m over the next four years. We recognise that relief for the carers is vital, and so is support.

I welcome funding of carer associations around the country as part of this Government's commitment to carers. These associations will keep carers informed about matters of interest. They provide counselling and training in appropriate areas. They also give carers the chance to get together and gain support from each other, to share information and experiences, and to strengthen their feeling of worth and self-esteem. The provisions in this Bill attempt to facilitate services which any government would wish to distribute to as great an extent as possible to meet the unmet needs within our community. It is a wonderful contribution to an area which is becoming maybe more and more of a concern to governments as we reach the turn of the century and as we come into that situation forecast for some years whereby the ratio of aged people by far outweighs the number of younger people who are in the work force and whose tax money is required to keep these services going. Sometimes priorities must be set. The right for a priority as far as this Government is concerned, and as far as I am concerned, is for those people who are most disadvantaged.

It is right and proper that any country that wants to deserve recognition as a decent country, a decent society, should put those who are most in need first when there is not an unlimited supply of revenue. This legislation addresses that very issue, and I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Laws Amendment Bill 1992 relates to control mechanisms in the immigration program. When the Migration Act was amended in 1989, part of the schema that was then proposed by the Government was to ensure that those categories of entry which were non-demand driven—that is, the categories of concessional and independent entry—should be capable of being capped. The fact is that in areas relating to preferential family reunion—for instance, spouse entry and entry for other close family members—the program is filled by the numbers of people wanting to apply to come to Australia. Those categories are regarded as being demand driven in the economic stream area.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, employer nominations can be demand driven. It is dependent upon the numbers of applications generated by employers who satisfy the relevant conditions and cannot find employees within Australia. If we have parts of the program driven by the numbers of applications that are received—that is, the numbers of people who satisfy the requirements—we need a program which can be limited to the particular numbers established by the Government in its announcements. We need to be able, in essence, to cap those categories which are non-demand driven. As I mentioned, they are the concessional and independent areas.

This was designed to prevent a blow-out in the immigration program. Even though we put those provisions in place in 1989, to this point in time they have not been used. The power was seen as being too blunt an instrument because it meant that the suspension of all applications would occur if the programs were capped. No processing would be undertaken. At a later point if it were decided to take the cap off the processing of new applications would continue but there would be enormous lags. The way in which the provision might operate could create a lack of fairness and equity between applicants.

It is obvious that the Government is now looking at the possibility of having to cap the program. The program numbers have come off to 80,000 this year in the Government's announced program. I assume that the basis for the Government looking at the way in which these provisions might operate and proposing fresh amendments is that it has in mind that it may need to use powers to suspend further processing in particular cases but did not wish to use the capping powers that were already there. Therefore, the Government has proposed in this Bill an alternative legislative scheme to cap various categories in the program.

This means that migration applications, even though the new capping arrangements could be used, can be accepted and held until the cap is either varied or lifted. It also means that those people who apply will not find that processing stops in relation to their applications if they are not successful; that is, they can be advised that their application has been rejected. Therefore, at least they will be informed of the outcome. It also means that the Government can continue to receive application fees and act in relation to those; that departmental officials in overseas posts will not suddenly become discharged of a workload if there is a suspension; and that there would be meaningful and useful activity in which they could be engaged. If the program cap is lifted at a later point, the matters can then be proceeded with, with some work having already been done.

The Bill also amends certain provisions to effect corrections to technical errors that arose in the Migration Amendment Act (No.2) 1991. Part 2 of the Bill establishes a scheme which will provide for the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to have a flexible power to publish in the Gazette an upper limit or cap on the number of visas in a specified class or classes that may be granted in a particular year. The cap may be imposed or lifted at any time during that year by announcement in the Government Gazette. It is clear that the capping powers are not to be applied to spouses, aged parents and dependent children; that is, the categories which are demand driven. Finally, in case the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) has any other concerns, I should say that the Opposition does not intend to oppose the introduction of this schema.

I do have a number of matters that I wish to raise. The Minister considered one of them and obtained certain advice. It is important that the issues be put clearly before the Parliament because there are certain principles in relation to migration entry which I think are important, which the Opposition believes are important, and which I believe are important to the Government. One of those is the principle that in our approach to immigration—regardless of whatever other criteria are used—country of origin, race, religion and matters of that sort shall not be used as a basis to choose between individual applicants.

It is important to note the basis upon which the Minister can impose ceilings on the numbers of visas that can be granted at overseas posts. The legislative schema will enable a cap to be established on the basis of particular posts. Therefore, with ceilings that are established on that basis, there is a potential or an appearance that factors other than merely of a planning nature could be taken into account. We are told that many of the factors that might be used would be past experience, anticipated demand, and matters of this sort which could well lead to variations between posts. That is a matter that I understand.

As I said, preferential category entrants will not be affected. This is only going to occur in the concessional independent areas. But if these ceilings are imposed, processing continues and visas are issued which are only valid for certain purposes, there is the potential that, if we put a quota on a particular post which is determined by discretion, some communities could look very critically at those matters. This is a question that needs to be addressed very sensitively and carefully.

Those groups, which often lobby and press for variations for particular reasons, ought to be assured that discriminatory factors of the sort that I am mentioning are not matters that shall be taken into account at all. I note that, in relation to this potential for possible discrimination, the Minister has sought advice from the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) that the provisions as drafted do not preclude judicial review as to the exercise of the discretionary power.

Particularly if there were improper use, I would regard racial factors, countries of origin and religion as being matters on which the Minister's judgment could be tested on that basis. I have sought privately from the Minister assurances in relation to this. He certainly tells me, and I am sure he will affirm, that if any misuse were to occur in this matter it would go very much against the spirit and the intent of these amendments and the policy that the Government would seek to apply and the policies that the Opposition would want to see applied.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a united front on that.

—I welcome that. The fact is that some provisions in this Bill, in the technical language used, although intended to operate in much the same form as provisions in the existing Act, could give rise to some difficulties because of the different wording. Argument could be adduced as a result of the different drafting that these provisions were intended to operate differently from those already in the Act. It seemed to me that this was a matter that needed to be put beyond doubt and that either the form of words used in the present Act should be changed to be consistent with the amendments proposed here or the words used in the existing Act should be used in this amending Bill. One way or another, the provisions should be brought into line.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the Minister's foreshadowed amendments to give effect to those changes. It seems to me that that will resolve any potential for difficulties that could arise with this legislation at a later time. Such legislation, which will become an Act of this Parliament, is increasingly the subject of careful consideration by legal advisers. It is becoming very much more technical in its application, and it is certainly desirable when drafting is undertaken to ensure that any possible difficulties of that sort are not left to be exploited.

It is important to note that we are dealing with legislation that is intended to give effect to the Government's announced intention to reduce the size of the immigration program this year to a figure of 80,000. As I mentioned, the capping power is an important facet in that regard. If one has regard to what are now the reported comments of the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), it reflects in part the coincidence of view that has been emerging between the Government and the Opposition.

The Minister will not find this in my notes, so he need not look to the advisers box to see where this inspiration comes from. But it is important to note that the Opposition has been arguing, during the worst recession in 60 years, for a much smaller immigration program. The honourable member for Calwell believes that the Minister has been undertaking these changes in some way in a game of catch-up with the Opposition. I would be the last to suggest that, although I am somewhat flattered by the comments of my colleague, which suggest that the approach—

TALK.START.PARA: —By whom?
—My colleague the honourable member for Calwell, who suggests—

—I do not know whether I want to get the Minister on the record as saying that about his colleague. The fact is that in this matter there have been adjustments, and those adjustments have moved in the same direction as the Opposition has been advocating for some time.

PARA.TAB: In the helpful way that I like to make suggestions in this area from time to time, I am sure the Minister has been apprised of some of my statements at other times suggesting further steps that the Government might properly take to ensure that the immigration program is more carefully structured and targeted. I know that my comments and those of my colleagues are sometimes misrepresented in this area. A document was published in the Minister's absence called Poles Apart. It had some critical observations to make about the approach that the Opposition takes in this area, but it is important to note that there are a number of ways in which the program might be more carefully targeted, firstly to limit abuse and, secondly, to ensure that it delivers an outcome that is more carefully attuned to our nation's national interest. That national interest is often reflected in the skills outcome of the program.

The Government, ever since the Fitzgerald report, has tended to emphasise over time that it pays special regard to the skills outcome and seeks to maintain that at the highest level. But the fact is that this year's program will see a substantially lower skills outcome than we have seen in recent years. It is a product of the way in which the Government's reduction of the program has been targeted. The Opposition in the way it defines skill—and this was revealed in certain Estimates debates in another place fairly recently—believes that the immediate relevance of skills that are acceptable to the Australian labour market is still not a matter that is taken into account, and certainly not a matter that is taken into account in determining the real skills level of the program. One can have people entering Australia with skills which may be recognised but which will never have the potential to be used, and which by the time they can be used, when the domestic labour market improves, will probably no longer be current because people have lacked the opportunity to use them.

It is certainly the Opposition's view that the immigration program needs to be more carefully targeted to ensure that the Australian labour market is one of the factors included in any points testing arrangements. The Opposition is also of the view that, if this country is going to more carefully structure its immigration program, access to benefits is a matter that needs to be addressed in a much more determined way than has been undertaken by the Government to date.

I welcome, as the Minister may have observed in some comments that I have made elsewhere, the Government's introduction in the recent Budget of a six-month restriction on access to benefits. But, were the Government to follow the Opposition's approach wholly, I believe it would have a significant impact on the way in which the program is presently targeted and would address much of the aspect of the present program whereby people have sought to come here, even in the context of the disastrous unemployment situation, because benefits are generally accessible after a short period and are still somewhat generous when compared to the circumstances that might apply in their homeland. That is an important factor to which the Government has not paid sufficient regard.

I have made some other comments in relation to the area of spouse entry. Of the order of 26,000 spouses and de facto partners are expected to enter Australia under the present immigration program. While nobody would want to deny genuine spouses or de facto partners the opportunity of joining their companion here in Australia, I think one would always be of the view that migration entry ought not to be manipulated by a fabricated relationship. This is an important matter and it has been, I think, well-addressed by the Government in relation to those people applying for a grant of resident status in Australia, but in relation to those people who are entering Australia from offshore it has still not been adequately addressed.

It is a well-known matter of anecdotal evidence in many communities that people still enter Australia in relationships when their principal purpose is migration and they have no intention of remaining in that relationship. Although the great bulk of the 26,000 people who enter Australia come under marriage relationships, it seems to me still one-third or more enter under de facto relationships. Evidence given to the parliamentary Committee some time ago was that there is always some greater element of doubt about people's bona fides in the area of de facto relationships.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are very careful.

—I understand people endeavour to question people's bona fides, and we have all seen the film Green Card. I am sure officials try to have regard to many of the techniques disclosed in that, but it certainly seems to me that the provisions which were sought by the Government domestically—that is, for those applying for a grant of resident status whereby a period of two years temporary entry was given—were not unreasonable provisions for application for those entering Australia from offshore; in other words, to see whether the relationship is of a continuing nature after a reasonable period of time.

PARA.TAB: Certainly experienced practitioners to whom I have spoken believe that it would be very difficult for people to maintain a fraudulent relationship for a two-year period if it were to be tested. I would also suggest, given the evidence the parliamentary Committee received, that a period longer than six months in a de facto relationship ought to be taken into account. This may require the amendment of some other legislation such as the sex discrimination legislation. I do not regard that as being at all unreasonable.

I note that the Citizenship Act is already an Act, as the courts interpret it, in which there are different provisions operating for those who marry as distinct from those who are in de facto relationships, and it seems to me that distinction ought to be made in relation to immigration entry arrangements, which are of far greater import.

The six-month period of cohabitation is certainly far too short. As I understand it, that provision was forced upon the Government as a result of a view as to the way in which the Sex Discrimination Act would apply in this area. The Minister looks puzzled, but it is my understanding that the view was that by the time people gave relevant notice, entered into a marriage relationship and made their bookings at the church or whatever, it would probably take about six months for a pair to be able to enter into such a relationship, and that if one had to find a roughly equivalent period for a de facto relationship which presumably could commence on the date when people say, `We are now living together', six months was roughly equivalent. In my view that is not a proper basis upon which to determine the important decision of migration entry, and it is a matter I think the Government can properly address.

Similarly, I think people entering into second, third or fourth relationships with people offshore is a serious matter. Although a good deal of counselling goes on and although there is more careful scrutiny when people do not seem to be able to make their relationships work and continue to go offshore looking for a marriage partner, in my view the relatively short periods of time in which people can undertake such a new relationship when their first one breaks down fairly quickly after entry to Australia is a matter that ought to be addressed in a regulatory way.

Similarly, as I understand is the case in the United States, there are provisions which already do limit people who wish to achieve permanent entry to Australia as spouses of Australian citizens or permanent residents. There ought to be restrictions in terms of their capacity to go offshore if the marriage relationship breaks down in a relatively short period after their arrival in Australia. I have been apprised of cases where people have come here, waited until permanent residency is granted, moved out of the relationship almost immediately and then sought to sponsor a new partner from offshore. These people ought not be rewarded if the original intention was to use an Australian permanent resident or citizen for the purpose of obtaining migrant entry with no intention of a genuine, long term relationship.

These are other matters the Minister can properly take up. They would have a significant impact upon spouse entry, which has been one of the fastest growing areas of the program. If this were to be far more carefully targeted the number of spouse entrants would be reduced quite considerably. It would not deny genuine spouses the opportunity to come to Australia, but it would ensure that those people who are abusing the system are weeded out.

The impact would be quite significant also in terms of the skill level. I certainly would not want to make the change in relation to refugees as I take the view that we have a very special responsibility in relation to refugees, but it is the fact that the degrading of the skill level occurs most significantly in the area of refugee entry and in the preferential family stream. As they are the areas in which this occurs, we have to be much more careful to ensure that any abuse is in fact contained.

As I have done in other forums, I offer these comments in a very constructive and positive way. Certainly I encourage the Minister to take them up. I have no objection to plagiarism in this area. I do not know what the honourable member for Calwell might say about it if the Minister were to take up any of these matters, but I think these are very useful issues to be addressed.

I have not commented on the refugee area because I know it is likely, separately, to be the subject of legislation during this session. It is another area, of course, in which there is abuse and great care needs to be taken. I am sure that the legislation the Minister will bring forward at a later point in time will be a careful and thoughtful response to those shortcomings.
