To that extent, of course, we will carefully review it, and to the extent that it meets the sorts of objectives that we have highlighted from time to time undoubtedly it will receive the same sort of thoughtful and constructive passage that this legislation has received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Previous speakers in this debate have emphasised that the Migration Laws Amendment Bill deals with capping and entrenching in relation to the Migration Act 1958. The background to that is the 12 May announcement of the intake for the coming year, which envisaged substantial reductions in the Government's expected intake and, more particularly, a decrease to 80,000. It contained major retractions in specific areas—the concessional family category falling from 19,000 to 6,000 and independents from 30,000 to nearly 13,500, as well as in relative terms a significant decrease in employer nominations. The background of this decrease in the intake forms the central need to give the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) power to cap.

PARA.TAB: The previous speaker, the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), said that there might have been a coincidence of policy rather than any attempt to catch up with Opposition views in this policy area. I think that is very much the case. Very few of us are so immune to society and so separate from what is occurring around us as to be unaware of concerns out there in the wider electorate about migration levels, the nature of the intake and its alleged relationship with employment patterns. Clearly the Government has felt the same pressures as many of those opposite about where it should go in this policy area. It is largely coincidental rather than an attempt to beat the Opposition out there in the racist marketplace.

I will speak later about some statements made by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) dealing with the inter-relationship of the economy and migration. This suggestion to cap gives the Minister substantial power to avoid what has been described by other speakers as the bluntness of the current provisions in relation to the processing of visas under section 28 and permits through section 40. People are aware of statements by the Minister pointing to some of the problems that arise from not moving down this road. It has been claimed that otherwise we would have the needless suspension of processing, even in contexts where people would not be permitted to come into the country anyway. They would not be processed, they would be sitting around facing what is largely a non-event, and indeed would not even get into the country in the first place.

Furthermore, it has been claimed that the absence of this kind of power would lead to fairly uneven workload patterns throughout the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and, I guess, the posts themselves. I think we are already aware that the degree of pressure on various overseas posts is very diverse. It relates to the internal situations in those countries, the nature and level of the community within this country, and the connections with the homeland. All of those are crucial elements in the level of demand at those posts.

To deny the Minister the right to move in this direction could, it has been correctly alleged, lead to a worsening pattern which sees concessional family claims taking 15 months in Pretoria, only four months in Auckland and 23 months in Beijing. Equally, in the independent category there would be a time scale in Manila of 20 months and in Tokyo of six. The uneven workload patterns and the inability of the Minister to allow posts to have caps are amongst the reasons one has to consider.

The intake this year has targeted particular components of the overall intake. Certain categories have decreased more than others. Others in both relative and absolute terms have decreased markedly. Without this capping, the position would be far more difficult. It should be said that this capping concept cannot apply to all areas. As indicated earlier, others are demand-influenced. It is clear that aged parents, dependent children and spouses in the immediate family are not affected.

A variety of comments were made about the skills component. I think we have to be realistic that the overall migration policies of the past few years have been centrally identified, with an increased requirement for English. This has been evident in the new stipulations in regard to business migration, which were influenced by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, and in the number of categories which in future will require knowledge of English as prescribed in a recent ministerial announcement.

There are certain components in the program which take account of the fact that refugees may not have been to Oxford or Cambridge and that spouses are not necessarily intellectual giants. At the same time this Government has made a very real attempt through the points system to ensure that people gain entry for concrete reasons and having reached certain educational levels, rather than for nebulous reasons.

We do have a program that looks at the degree to which we recognise overseas institutions. Those concepts are now central to a large part of the migration intake. They form a background to this legislation. There has been an attempt by the Government more clearly to target the intake to ensure that whilst there are very obvious humanitarian requirements, at the same time the Government moves to a greater emphasis on English requirements. It looks to the way in which English is delivered to incomers, and looks more clearly at the skills required. Indeed, the honourable member for Dundas said that in the past year the points system was altered in relation to the time when people obtained their qualifications overseas.

In recent days the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has made a number of statements. I would like to deal with his comment on 10 October that every major study on this matter has reflected the negative impacts of migration. I prefer to be a little more agnostic about this issue. I do not really think the evidence is so emphatically black and white that we can say that absolutely and for certain all case studies point to negative impacts of migration.

It is all right to say that Australia's greatest slippage in OECD terms occurred during a period of peak migration, but many factors have to be taken into consideration in order to arrive at the exact reasons for any such statement. It is questionable to say that it is crucially, absolutely and totally related to the level of migration intake. I do not subscribe to the view that we can say that migration is the be-all and end-all, that it massively and decisively increases our productivity and that without it we would be a hopeless nation. It would be incorrect to say that every study has pointed in this direction.

Whilst I agree with the honourable member for Kalgoorlie that we cannot rely on bodies such as the Bureau of Immigration Research as an objective judge and say that its papers are indicative, I would point to the fact that a large number of writers who are in no way bound to the Bureau say that the question is broader. Brian Parmeter in Economic Papers of June 1990 commented:

SPEECH.PARA: Even with a more careful definition of the questions to be posed and improvements in the analytical framework, more convincing research on the long term effects of immigration will still depend on more convincing empirical work.
John Perkins stated in the National Economic Review of April 1992:

Output in 1988 is estimated to have been 18 per cent above what it would have been had there been no immigration . . . output per capita increased as a result of immigration . . . the interpretation of such parameters is that a 10 per cent increase in factor inputs will generate an increase in output of 11.5 per cent for manufacturing and 12.8 per cent for the economy as a whole . . . these results relate to the combined effects of scale economies and embodied technological changes, so encompassing that part of technological development occurring with the investment, with associated scale of production.
Glenn Withers commented in the Australian Journal of International Affairs of May 1991:
Very recent work finds a short term surplus, medium term debt and long term surplus on trade due to immigration. The long term benefit means that the medium term debt is `good' debt not `bad' debt.

I do not think we can be absolutist and say that all evidence goes in one direction. But, clearly, the background to this decision to reduce the intake is a realisation that even those who defend migration acknowledge that in the short term the transfer payments go against the countries accepting migrants. There is an acknowledgment that the electorate feels that in the current very severe recession we cannot afford those short term costs. I put the view that there is a lot more work to be done on this. We cannot say that one writer has clearly proven to each and every one of us that there are no gains.

PARA.TAB: The other aspect on which the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has spoken in recent days—and I would like to express some agreement with him—is the inability of the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) to understand his role as Chairman of the Caucus committee and of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. There seems to be an inability to accept that those holding the position of chairman of a committee are not there to represent their views alone; they have the right to criticise policy in that area but must give the appearance to the general public that they are representing the Committee as opposed to themselves as individuals. I think that is a great danger in this policy area at the moment. As we see in Europe at the moment, it can create great tensions and great divisions in a society.

The problem has been quite clearly indicated in a recent report to this Parliament by the Migration Regulations Committee: that one member would seemingly usurp the role of Chairman to parade his own views, which are a distinct minority view within that Committee. I think we have the same problem within the Caucus committee. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie quite correctly referred to the document Towards a Fairer Immigration System for Australia. That document is seemingly paraded as a document of the Party and of a committee in a particular policy area which has never been brought before the Committee and six months later has not even been sighted by that Committee. In recent times the honourable member for Kalgoorlie has quite correctly indicated concern that people would parade themselves, perhaps as alternative Ministers, as people who should be given the licence to go to conferences.

As indicated in the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 September 1992, where a clearly distinct policy is seemingly enunciated by the Chairman, it is quite at variance to the continued support of the Caucus committee for the Minister's position in these matters. As I say, they are matters of concern in this policy area. This legislation is clearly designed to bring in necessary reductions.

I refer briefly to the comments of the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs in regard to spouses. Any member who is in his electoral office often enough knows that, for all of the anecdotal evidence out there, the fact of life is that one has people coming into one's office every day of the week who have been refused permission to bring their wives into Australia because some bloke in Beirut cannot name the suburb of Sydney where the mosque or Maronite church is in which they are to be married. That is the kind of question the Department goes in for these days. We have the situation where the spouse of a person who is doing two different jobs a week and also studying is refused admission to this country because the authorities are not sure whether the spouse in Australia is a worker or a student. Quite obviously, this is indicative of very severe questioning by the Department. Those of us who have these cases coming in every day of the week are aware of the very strenuous efforts the Department is making to ensure that people are not very easily rorting the system.

I for one think the six-month period for a de facto relationship is quite reasonable. All we will accomplish by an increase is contrived attempts to get extensions of visas. This is already happening; people who have been with someone for five months are coming in wanting to get another two months for some purported reason so they will get over the six-month period. I do not think that will make a very concrete contribution to solving the problems.

I might be out of tune with the design of the policy, but I would have thought that changing the rules in relation to people who marry when on tourist visas as opposed to those coming from offshore is designed not so much to attack fraudulent marriages as such but, as part of a general pattern, to start undermining a feeling overseas that people can just walk into Australia and, by some contrivance—not only that one—engineer permanent residence. It is part of that general pattern that we have not only in marriage, and something that I think both sides of the House would seek to diminish.

I for one, as I say, do not advocate increasing the requirements for de facto relationships or engineering a situation where all couples have to live together for two years before they can get permanent residence. We all know that it is a fact of life that relationships crash—they can crash in a particularly short time—and to start penalising these people just because of `anecdotal evidence' is just not good enough.

On the other hand, I think the suggestion by the shadow Minister in regard to relationships which collapse too soon and which then allow someone very quickly to bring another person in from offshore has a lot of validity. I recommend the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My concern with the Migration Laws Amendment Bill is that it relates essentially to the indecision by the Government as to what sort of a migration quota it wants for 1992-93. While I have understood something of the dilemma of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand), it seems to me that the extent to which we have had a whole array of changes to the migration laws has promoted a good deal of concern in the community as to just where we are going and what the basis of future migration policy will be.

PARA.TAB: We on this side have said for a long time that, at a time of high unemployment and economic downturn, unless we are prepared to reduce the number of migrants coming into this country we will have a great many problems. This law provides for the suspension of the processing of visa applications and changing the basis of determining visas on a quantifiable basis. This smacks to me a little like the Minister deciding after the event that he believes he has to intrude, and illustrates to me that he is not sure just what the Government's policy will be.

In the nature of migration at the moment there are three factors that do not necessarily flow from this legislation but are certainly matters before the community. I am quite aware that on the refugee scene the Minister has sought some capacity to balance those who apply for migration in the normal course against those who are applying for determination of refugee status.

TALK.START.PARA: —My worry as far as the refugees are concerned is that we run the risk at the moment of distorting our priorities for those who apply for migration in the normal course because of the overwhelming load of refugees, particularly the Chinese students, who seek change of status in a way that affects the priorities that should properly be accorded those who have been on the waiting lists and, because of a number of restrictions, are likely to be deferred for a number of years. Of course there is a problem with administering them, and there is a division within the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, of which there has been some mention in this debate and other debates in this House over the last little while. Some members of that Committee say a more sympathetic approach has to be taken to allow an extension of the temporary entry permit or in some way to perpetuate a situation which gives those involved a permanently different status from every other person in Australia, while others, according particularly to the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), will be in a position of rejecting the Chairman's advice.

PARA.TAB: As far as I am concerned, the recommendations of that Committee are clear. I know that the Minister has some sympathy for that point of view, and I hope that he will accept those recommendations.

As I say, the first problem in the whole field—and I am interested in the way in which the Minister will respond—is the extent to which we seem to me to be hooked on a predicament that has been generated by successive Prime Ministers with inadequate advice which means that we will give priority to those who may not be classified as persons who are in genuine fear of persecution were they to return to their homeland against those who apply for migrant status in the normal course. That to me is the first and most fundamental quandary in the whole field of the administration of immigration at the moment.

The second area that worries me relates to the determination of who will be accepted or rejected under this legislation. One of my worries in the general field of migration is the extent to which the Minister and his Government are allowing what I see as a tendency for migrants to retain their separateness rather than to become Australians. I know that it is a very difficult subject. If we are going to grow as a nation, we have to ensure that in the future the children of migrants have the same priorities that, in my view, children of new Australians had in the past. I have been delighted at the number of those who, whatever their origins, be they second generation Australians, those who were born outside Australia or those who were born immediately after their parents' arrival in Australia, have adopted a total Australian identity. The Australianisation of Australia, whoever the migrants are—old or new—is pre-eminent in my consideration of migrant policy.

I am worried that—and this comes under the ethnic affairs part of the Minister's portfolio—today we tend to be too inclined to allow people to assert their separateness rather than their identity as Australians. I do not know that the Minister is necessarily of that view. While protecting, as we should, the rights of people to practise their religion, to maintain their customs and to preserve their heritage, we must not allow migrants ever to think that, if they are going to accept Australian citizenship, they should do other than see the English language and their Australian identity as pre-eminent in what they do. I do not see this second problem as necessarily flowing from this legislation; it is just part of the whole dimension of where we go in the administration of the policies of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs.

The third area in this general field that concerns me is the problem of knowing who and what sort of a balance of people will be allowed in the future. I know there are problems with those who come in under a business category as business migrants. I do not think the Government has given enough consideration to what I see as people with skills. Family reunion is an emotional part of our migration policy, but, as you well know, Mr Deputy Speaker, if we are going to allow the migrants of the future to contribute to our well-being, it is those with skills who will essentially make a more significant contribution than those who come in simply because of family reunion.

I understand that people who come to Australia want to bring their families; they want to allow their closest blood relatives to come in too. But I am worried that, with the sorts of policies that this legislation reflects, there will still be a maintenance of what I would see as a disproportionate percentage of newcomers coming under that family reunion category rather than those that I would see as best suited to contribute to the advancement of Australian interests. Of all the areas in migration policy, that worries me the most.

Under this legislation, the Minister will have the capacity to provide limits on visas and treat migrants in a way that might well allow him to meet numerical quotas. But it is the quantitative and qualitative approach that need to be blended one to the other. Quality does not mean that one is looking at anything other than Australia's interests. I would hope that, in his interpretation of this legislation, the Minister might consider, to a greater degree than I think the present Labor Government has, the necessity for people coming into Australia not just to be here because Australia wants an augmentationist population, but because those who come to Australia can contribute to a better country. I have been most concerned that, in adopting migration policies over the last nine years of Labor administration, we have let the heart rule the head a little too much.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't want to be a dumping ground.

—We certainly do not want to be a dumping ground. We have to have compassion. We have to allow for refugees. We have to treat refugees fairly and equitably. But I hope to goodness that the Minister does not have in mind maintaining too great a percentage of those who are here simply on the basis of family reunion. I want people who will contribute to a better Australia. To my mind, that is the pre-eminent priority that I would give to the whole field of this legislation, including the administration of migrant policy.

PARA.TAB: I see the legislation as another example of the Minister being unable to make up his mind as to what we have for the future. I know he has had problems. I am concerned about the quality of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The advice received by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations suggests to me that the Committee is not in as good a state as it should be. For example, I have been appalled at the lack of knowledge of conditions in countries from which we source migrants. It might well be that information given to some of the officers of the Department is better than that given to the Committee. But it really appals me that there seems to be so little communication between the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Immigration Department.

As the Minister would know, in our last report we made reference to the fact that there does need to be greater communication of information in the countries of source. This applies perhaps even more to refugees than it does to migrants. If people are going to be returned to their country of origin, we do not want to put them in a position of having their lives at risk and, consequently, we do not want to be seen as returning them to circumstances that are not acceptable in the normal course of the humane treatment of people. I think that is where this definition of refugees and the reasonable fear of persecution takes pre-eminence. I trust that, in the quality of that advice, as in other advice, the Department is not as bad as I have felt at times it has been in the evidence it has given to the Migration Regulations Committee.

I have no objection to this legislation. I am more concerned about the quality of administration than the manner of administration. I regret that we seem to have so many changes in regulations and the legislation that it must be extraordinarily difficult for those in the community seeking to give advice to know just where we are going. It is a very important field. It is one that has as much significance today as it ever has in Australia's progress. I would hope that the economic management of Australia will improve so that unemployment can be reduced and the fear that so many existing residents and citizens of Australia have about migrants might be allayed.

It is this blend between the need to try to contribute to Australia's well-being and the meeting of our humanitarian obligations that essentially lies behind so many of the changes that I know the Minister has made in the legislation. It is not just a matter of emotion; it should be a matter of our trying to look at Australia's interests first. I sometimes suspect that electoral pressures within electorates may be the basis for the changes that the Minister has pursued, rather than what would be in the long term a continuation of the best migrant policy that has motivated the changes. I hope that it is the latter, not the former. I will be interested to see how the Minister administers his task as it may not necessarily be the way that I see it.

I take no objection to the legislation, but I express my concerns about aspects of what I believe is one of the most emotional and significant areas of government policy and where I believe there has been too little notice taken of the priorities that Australia should give, as distinct from the priorities that I suspect electorally and humanitarianly seem to persuade the Government. For it is in that area that I think the Government has acted against what I would see as the preferred course in the administration of this extraordinarily important area of government policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have long held a view that Ministers who do not intend to stand for re-election should stand down from their positions. I believe that they tend to be lame ducks in their positions and cannot contribute well to their portfolios. But that is a generalisation and, like all generalisations, it is not always true.

PARA.TAB: I pay tribute to the present Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand). The present Minister is, in my view, one of the most courageous Ministers we have had in a long time. I think that he has done a very good job under very difficult circumstances. I know some of the pressures that have been on this Minister, in what the previous speaker, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) referred to as a very emotive issue. I think that he stuck to his guns extremely well. He was heard to comment some time ago about the lawyers. He used some adjectives that Minister Hand is prone to use. They would not be allowed by you, Mr Deputy Speaker, so I will not use them. But I think he is quite right.

Senator Walsh was undoubtedly the best Minister for Finance we have seen in this Parliament for a long time. Senator Walsh, by his control of the outlays, was the man who made the reputation of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) as the world's greatest Treasurer; that was really done on the outlays side of the Budget by Senator Walsh. I think a lot of people, even those on the other side of the House, would agree with that.

When I asked Senator Walsh what he thought was important, he said, `To keep the b. . . .. lawyers away from the money'. He is absolutely right. We have to keep the lawyers away from the money if we want the economy to run properly. If we want immigration to run, we certainly have to keep the lawyers away from immigration. They are a self-servicing breed that has done enormous damage. Again, that is a generalisation which is not always true, but it is a generalisation which is pretty accurate.

I make no bones about it, I support this legislation because it is a tentative step in the right direction; it is the first, faltering step down the road to lowering the migration intake overall. Migration is simply an idea whose time has passed. This country no longer needs large immigration. If we look at the history, we see that Australia's economy was at its best—we were the country with the leading standard of living in the world—when we had a low population and we had a lot of resource exports.

It is rather amusing, and rather sad, to see the antics of the mining industry. The great Australian mining industry seems to be led by people who do not have a clue where their self-interests lie. Particularly disappointing is Hugh Morgan, a man who is seen by the mining industry as a loose cannon on the deck and whose utterances tend to terrify it. Occasionally he gets it right; he got it right about the Mabo case in the paper yesterday but, generally, Morgan is horrendously wrong. He is certainly wrong in immigration when he calls for half a million migrants a year. He tries to dress this up as some sort of humanitarian exercise. Do honourable members have any idea what that would do to the Australian economy? It might provide very cheap labour for Mr Morgan's mines, but it certainly would not be in the interests of the economy or of the people of this country. When we listen to the utterances of a lot of the senior people in the mining industry, we find that they all seem to advocate high immigration. They ought to go back and do some thinking about where their own self-interest lies.

Refugees are a case that we have to consider; there is no doubt about that. I have been involved in a lot of refugee cases, not quite so much in the last few years, but for a time I probably did more refugee work than just about anyone in this Parliament. I have an abiding sympathy for people who need refuge, but this cannot and should not ever be allowed to extend to economic refugees. Australia cannot solve the world's economic problems and it would be foolish for us to do so, or to give any inkling that we intend to try. Therefore, we have to take a very hard line with refugees and make sure that they are political refugees.

Australia, by world standards, does more than its share of taking political refugees; by world standards, it does a good job. We take these refugees because of the compassionate humanitarian nature of Australia—not because of some perceived obligation to the world, or the world order. We do it of our volition because we think that it is the right thing to do.

I recall just after the ascension of the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) to his position as Leader of the Opposition that he made a statement calling for reduced immigration. I think that he had, in fact, read my paper and realised the good commonsense of it. He was immediately denounced by the Prime Minister as a racist. This has been the ploy: whenever anything is suggested about cutting immigration, the immigration industry charges in and calls you a racist. I defended the Leader of the Opposition in the media and said that there was absolutely nothing racist in what he said. Lo and behold, he went on television that night and said, `I am not a racist'—I am paraphrasing because I cannot remember the words exactly—`When the economy improves, I will vastly increase immigration'. He then compounds his error by saying, `If I don't, somebody else will make us do it'. So he gave away national sovereignty as well. It is quite clear that the objective of the Opposition is to buckle to this so-called world pressure. If so, those opposite will be able to make some very large savings because they will be able to abolish our military forces—we will not need them. I think this is something that is obviously hidden in Fightback; it has not been spelled out. It is clearly the intention because the Leader of the Opposition said that world pressure would determine the best interests of Australia. That is a nonsense. Australia must always look to its own interests. Nobody else will do this for us; no world order will look after our interests.

I say very clearly that there is only one ground for immigration: net benefit to Australia. If there is no net benefit, then there should be no immigration. I believe that a total of 50,000 is a target we should aim for. The Minister's target of 80,000 is on the way down, and I certainly commend him for that.

It should be remembered that we lose about 30,000 migrants a year. So we are only talking about 20,000 positive out of a total of 50,000. There is always going to be the overwhelmingly compassionate case and the occasional case where somebody has a skill or an expertise that the country needs. Therefore, we need to have some mobility, some fluidity there somewhere, but certainly no more than that.

The previous speaker talked about bringing in migrants with special skills. I would have thought that it would have been much better to train the people of Australia, to train Australians for those skills. If we do not do that, we feed animosity into the system, which continues to grow and to gnaw at society, as Australians simply see their position being usurped by foreign expertise that is brought in when the country already has an obligation to train its own people first. I say to those who pursue this argument of immigration for the sake of special skills that they should really look at what they are doing because they are undermining the whole basis of the training of Australians.

People who impact on immigration were also alluded to in the debate. Quite frankly, I think the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade needs very close scrutiny. Its performance is, in many ways, quite appalling and I blame it rather than the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs for some of the pressures that lead to the decisions we make in immigration.

I have the distinction of having been censured by this Parliament on an occasion several years ago when I said that we should slow down South East Asian immigration to a level which Australia can accommodate. I did not think it was particularly racist; I thought it was good commonsense, but it was deemed as racist by the then Prime Minister. He moved a motion which was jubilantly supported by the Opposition and by my own Party, and I was duly censured. I accept that. I was rather annoyed that the toy Parliament in Western Australia then sought to also censure me for the same thing when I considered that it was none of its business. On that occasion, the only support I got was from Asians. I got a lot of support from this source. It was basically two sorts: what I call the Sri Lankan or the old Ceylon Asians, the Asians who did not want to be Asian and their line has tended to be, `We have been brought up with a British culture, English is our language. We think that this is a superior culture and we want to be Australian'.

The other support I got was basically from the Chinese, whose line was, `Look, this is the greatest country in the world and we really don't want all these migrants messing it up. We don't want them upsetting things. We too think there should be some restraint'. So I think there is some evidence that Australia is subjecting itself far too much to the cringe; that we must adopt these policies otherwise other people will not like us.

I have an electorate with a lot of migrants in it. In fact, I think it would be one of the top six migrant electorates in the country. I find that my migrants, overwhelmingly, want to be Australian, and they want their kids to be Australian. They came to Australia because they saw it as the land of the future for their kids. I can tell honourable members that the last thing that migrants who came here for a future for their kids want to see is that future being undermined by migrants. So honourable members do not have to fear lowering immigration in respect of the migrant vote because most migrants understand full well the consequences of uncontrolled immigration.

One of the problems we have in this country is the enormous coverage of the media when, largely through ignorance, it panders to such charlatans as Phil Ruthven, the futurologist, the man who sees Australia with a population of 150 million people—mostly Asian, he says—and this population driving the economy of this country. In fact, it will give us a living standard something like that of Bangladesh. It might be what Mr Phil Ruthven wants; he would see himself as up at the top. But they are certainly not the conditions I want for my kids, and I will be opposing that implacably. I think Mr Ruthven talks so much drivel that it is time the press started to look at him critically and determine just exactly what he is saying. It ought to look at his utterances of 10 years ago and ask whether it can honestly say the predictions and forecasts he made then are coming to fruition.

It has been said that migration increases per capita output. This is simply one of those statements that are not true. Migration does not produce increased per capita output at all. It increases total output, obviously, but more often than not it works to reduce per capita output. For Australia, productivity must be the name of the game. We are not going to get productivity with a migration problem. It has been conservatively estimated that immigration is costing this country in the region of $9 billion a year. I often think it is rather amusing for us in the Labor Party to talk eloquently and enthusiastically about waterfront reform. Things are getting better on the waterfront. When we get all the waterfront reform we want it will save about $1 billion a year. Big deal! It will be nice to have and we are on the way to getting it, but it pales into insignificance against the cost of immigration—immigration which we could fix at the stroke of a pen if we had the nerve to do it. Of course, we have not and neither has the Opposition.

We talk about the categories of migrants that we want in this country. I say again that the only reason for immigration is net benefit to Australia. For this reason, the family concessional program must go. It was based on a fallacy from its inception. While I think one would have to give the dubious credit to Al Grassby for starting the idea and pushing mass immigration, it really was Malcolm Fraser who institutionalised it. It was a Liberal Minister who brought in this family concessional program, the idea being at the time that those opposite could buy votes. Of course, votes cannot be bought, and if we believe that we can manipulate the ethnic vote then we are saying that ethnics are inherently more stupid than Australians—and I do not believe that. I believe it is a racist concept and it is one that I totally reject. I reject it from experience. The rule of thumb is quite simple: rich migrants vote for those opposite and the poor ones vote for us. That is a generalisation that can be substantiated by a review of the ballot boxes. There are other factors that will affect it of course but, as a generalisation, that tends to be true.

There is a category of migration which I think does need some consideration: working holiday visas. These visas are negotiated with various countries, and I think there are about six at the moment. We have reciprocal rights for people to come to Australia to work in the country for no more than three months at any one job to get valuable experience. My experience has been, representing a large electorate, parts of which are certainly isolated, that these young holiday visa workers go to these remote areas and perform a very good service. These are young people who are prepared to make a commitment to Australia. Rather than seeing them as queue jumpers, I would much prefer to see an expansion of the working holiday visa program and the total abandonment of the family concessional program which offers Australia nothing. As the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) said, we have to get some unity, some Australianisation into the community, and I think these young people who come out with an obvious commitment to Australia are the sorts of people that, if we are going to have migrants, would make by far and away the best sort of migrants.

Other areas that have to be considered here include the fact that immigration is impacting not only on our unemployment figures but also on the cost of running the country. In the present climate these immigrants impact almost always directly on the dole. This country had a textile, clothing and footwear industry, and an automotive industry. Then along came the myth of the level playing field—a myth subscribed to by both political parties. We have seen a massive scaling down of these industries but we are still bringing in the same migrants that used to feed them. Of course there is nowhere else for them to go but straight onto the dole. This is such palpable nonsense that it ought to be stopped forthwith.

It is, however, not as simple as that. In my own electorate there is the township of Leinster. Leinster today would be about 80 per cent New Zealander. The reason for this is that when jobs become available in this mining town they are not advertised. The New Zealanders simply get their cousins from New Zealand. With communications and rapid travel, they can be there within a week. This denies those jobs to Australians and it impacts directly on the dole. It means that Australians who could be working and productive for this country simply are not earning the money. That is not all, however, because with these New Zealand migrants a lot of money is repatriated. While it is not directly germane to this Bill, as a government and as a country, we must hopefully get some consensus and look at the CER agreement because that agreement clearly is working to Australia's detriment and we are massively the net losers in this area.

I believe it is absolute nonsense to say that, in the present economic climate, we can allow the free entry of New Zealanders. I might add that some of the strongest representations I have had in this regard come from New Zealanders who have come to Australia, made a commitment to this country, pay their taxes in this country and are, in my view, extremely good citizens. They are the people who have come to me in the biggest numbers and said that it is about time we put the brakes on what they themselves see as a crazy situation.

Migration has served this country well in the past. It is, however, as I said earlier, an idea whose time has passed. We must be prepared to rethink the whole situation. I think there are substantial environmental reasons why we should be limiting immigration. It is a fact that the great majority of immigrants impact on Melbourne and Sydney. I can remember when I was a kid that people used to take water from Melbourne to Adelaide to put with the scotch because Melbourne's water was so good; it is no longer the case. In Sydney there are tremendous problems, and land prices—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with Melbourne water?
—It is not as good as it used to be.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. M.J.R. MacKellar)—Order! The Minister will not interject from out of his place.

TALK.START.PARA: —And certainly not to me, otherwise I might get nasty.

PARA.TAB: Mr Hand interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not yet. I think there are very good environmental reasons for stopping immigration. I commend the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs for this Bill. I commend him for his vision and say that this is a start in the right direction and hope that the current migration numbers can be continued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always interesting to listen to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). I hope he does not get nasty with me when I suggest that in his reference to Fightback he is totally off the beam. There is no hidden agenda for the coalition, once we win the next election, to abolish the defence forces of this country. As I have said, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie is totally wrong and off the beam in that area.

PARA.TAB: However, I do agree with the honourable member for Kalgoorlie when he makes the comment that the prime purpose of migration is to benefit Australia. I have no hesitation in agreeing totally with that. As far as I am concerned, if we leave aside the humanitarian questions of refugees, that is really the only reason for having a migration program. I make no apology for that. I am Australian and proud of it. All of the activities of this Government and any government should be directed to the benefit of Australia.

Of course, the main purpose of this Bill is to allow the Minister to determine the maximum number of visas or specified classes that may be granted in a program financial year or, as the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) put it in the second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: Effective management of the migration program is essential in ensuring that planned program outcomes are not exceeded.

The Act currently contains a suspension power in section 28 which allows the Minister to suspend the processing of applications for visas in a specified class. That suspension power does not apply to applicants who may be the spouse, child or aged parent of an Australian citizen; that is quite right and quite appropriate. The suspension power in section 28 has never been exercised. Nonetheless, it does remain a very potent tool, albeit rather blunt in its application. But, if applied, it would suspend all processing of applications, although not necessarily establishing a numerical limit.

PARA.TAB: The Government says that the amendments proposed will overcome these problems through supplementing the visa suspension powers. It is proposed to allow the application of numerical ceilings or caps for a specific visa class and to allow the processing of applications up to the point of grant. Under this Bill the Minister will have the power to decide on the number of visas in a specific category in a given year. At the same time there is no limit on the number of determinations that the Minister may make each year in deciding the maximum number of visas in each class. Potentially, once the cap has been reached in a certain class, it can be raised again through a new determination to increase allowable numbers. The number of classes under which visas are issued could also be broadened.

The Bill also gives the Minister the power to impose upper limits on the number of visas that can be granted at overseas posts. This provision takes into account the processing abilities and the workloads of different overseas posts. The capping provisions in the Bill will not apply to certain preferential visa classes. Therefore, as the Minister told the House on 19 August in the second reading speech, the Bill will allow the Minister to target the grant of visas in accordance with the priorities of the migration program.

Quite frankly, I have no argument with having provisions to ensure that the priorities of the migration program are met. The concern that I have is what the fundamental objectives of the migration program should be. We in the coalition are very much committed to the concept of multiculturalism. There is no argument about the contribution that people of various backgrounds and cultures have made to Australia, which is all the richer for that experience. We have benefited enormously from the cultural diversity of people who have come here from all over the world. We have endorsed programs to assist people to settle successfully in Australia, and the definition spelt out in the national agenda for a multicultural Australia.

We should recognise the difference between multicultural and multiculturalism. I see a vast difference between the application of a multicultural society and what could be described as professional multiculturalism. A multicultural outlook is one that holds respect for different cultures and community outlooks which are rooted in different traditions, religions and ethnic heritage. I suppose that is what I would call soft multiculturalism. But compare that with what one could term hard multiculturalism which in my book stands for the promotion, through administrative and educational intervention, of specific community group interests at the expense of others. Professional multiculturalism tends to establish ghettos and divisiveness that this country does not need and cannot afford. It can mean the promotion and protection of values at variance with broadly accepted attitudes of liberalism and plurality that Australia has thrived and developed upon.

I say quite specifically—I have said this before in this place—that we do not need to import hatreds or prejudices. We do not want vendettas from other societies; they should be left behind. What we need in the people who come here is that they have the desire, the wish and the will to become Australians. Quite frankly, there is nothing wrong with being Australian. I am passionately proud of being Australian and passionately proud of Australia. I value cultural diversity. But, if people want to come to Australia, they should accept the proposition that they come here to become Australians, not to become foreigners living in Australia but not part of our society.

I suppose I will be accused of racism, as I have been before. But I believe that it is important that people who come to Australia, to live in Australia and be Australians, should speak English; that is the language of this country. I believe we should be doing more as a society to help newcomers to learn it. I know that a lot has been done over decades. In fact my wife at one stage was a teacher of English as a foreign language to migrants. But we need to do much more because surely the cornerstone of acceptance and success in any society is being able to communicate in the language of that society. We should maintain cultural background by all means; I have no quarrel with that. But we need to accept and realise that Australia is a separate country and that we do not want to import, generate and foster the divisions that exist in so many other parts of the world. There is nothing wrong with wanting to have a peaceful, harmonious country in which people live in peace together.

This Bill offers the Minister the possibility of imposing quota systems at his discretion to favour certain visa categories, especially at overseas posts. I see in that a prospect and a danger of various interest groups lobbying for higher or lower ceiling numbers at various overseas posts, and this cannot be overlooked. By and large I would say that in the last decade throughout government in Australia, particularly in the Federal sphere, there has been an ongoing move to reduce and remove ministerial discretion. Quite frankly, I have no quibble with that. This move has reduced the potential for political interference, and I believe that is a good thing; I applaud that. I understand the need for the legislation—I certainly do—but I make the point that it does introduce some potential for that political interference that we are striving to remove.

I suppose this could be the kiss of death for the Minister because, like the member for Kalgoorlie, I certainly praise the present Minister. I think he has done the job very well indeed. He is not listening to me at present, but I am sure I will catch his attention sooner or later and he will hear the nice words I am saying about him. No, he continues not to pay attention, so perhaps I will change my opinion of him, but I do not think I will.

I have no fear with this Minister, nor would I have any doubts or worries about the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), who is sitting at the table and who, after the coalition wins the next election, will in all probability be the Minister for immigration. But I say to the present Minister and to all of those here: what if the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) was the Minister for immigration? Can honourable members imagine that one-man rabid faction as Minister for immigration with this power and this discretion in his hands? I suppose he will come in here in a moment, frothing at the mouth, and start yelling at me. That has happened before, and I am sure it will happen again. But the point that I am making is that that ministerial discretion is something that could be misused. As I have said, I have complete faith in the present Minister and in the gentleman who I believe will be the next Minister.

As I said earlier, I am concerned about the multicultural concept and I am not happy—in fact I am far from happy—with the way that Labor has managed to politicise the multicultural concept. Rather than leaving our various ethnic communities to settle in Australia, to find their own place and role in our nation and to fit comfortably into our culturally diverse and tolerant society, Labor has used multiculturalism for crude political purposes.

While there is no doubt that we do have some prejudice, I believe that basically we are a tolerant society. To some extent we may err too much on the side of saying, `She'll be right mate; she's okay; let's not worry about it'. I say again that I think the politicisation of the multicultural concept by the present Government has not served Australia well.

The Government seems to have endeavoured to secure sectional interests in marginal seats, to promote sectional interests for the sake of votes under the guise of multiculturalism. As I said before, the coalition welcomes the idea of a multicultural Australia but condemns the Government's repeated attempts to politicise the concept. Fightback endorses our approach to multiculturalism. It has specific commitments to settlement programs, to welcome and assist new arrivals, and funding has been specifically quarantined from expenditure reductions within Fightback.

This Bill gives the Minister the power to set ceilings on visa categories to meet the priorities of the national migration program. It is something which should be carefully and objectively utilised, and must not be used to help realise political goals rather than national goals. The coalition will be aiming at lower immigration targets. Our critics will undoubtedly accuse us of being against multiculturalism on that ground. Far from it. Our immigration program will be realistic, objective and help make Australia a better country for those already here, as well as future arrivals. I believe any government has a responsibility to those of us who are here, whether we are native born or come from other countries.

Despite what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) says, we are in a recession. He can quibble on the words but we are in a recession and the pain goes on. The current migrant intake is unsustainable in employment terms. It is not helping those migrants who are already here and those who are about to arrive in the expectation, sadly long out of date, that this is a country of great opportunity. I believe that it will be a country of great opportunity once again but at present that is not the case. It was once, but Labor has wrecked it and we will have to rebuild it.

There was an interesting article in today's Sydney Morning Herald, part of a series of articles which have brutally exposed the damage Labor has done to this country. The Government makes a lot of noise about the growth in employment in Australia over the past decade, claiming that employment has grown by 15.2 per cent between 1981 and 1988, according to the OECD. I might say that just in relation to the north coast of New South Wales in which my electorate of Cowper is situated the growth in employment in the six years to the end of 1990 was something in excess of 32 per cent—a very significant increase in employment which has been well above the Australian average. It is a factor which is not readily recognised by many people in the community, who seem to concentrate always on the very high unemployment figures, which comes by a lot of migration from the rest of Australia—not from outside Australia. It is internal migration because of our beautiful climate and the fact that if people have to be unemployed they would far prefer to be unemployed in Port Macquarie, Nambucca Heads or Coffs Harbour than in Geelong, Broken Hill or some place like that. The article in the Sydney Morning Herald stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Employment expanded by 15.2 per cent between 1981 and 1988, according to the OECD . . .
That certainly sounds impressive, especially when the nearest Western country to achieve similar growth was the United States with 14.7 per cent. The article continued:

PARA.TAB: Very impressive, until you look more closely at the figures, as the OECD and the Federal Government's Economic Planning Advisory Council . . . have done. One reason for the rapid growth was that Australia's population increased by 13.4 per cent during the period—again the highest figure in the OECD with the exception of Iceland. This was due mainly to immigration. More migrants mean a higher demand for goods and services and ultimately labour.

Taking into account the rise in population, jobs growth was not 15 per cent but 1.6 per cent—a barely average performance in the OECD and well below the 7.4 per cent achieved in the US and the 4.4 per cent in Canada.

SPEECH.PARA: This highlights the need for a controlled and sensible approach to migration—not a political multicultural one. Also, we must take into account the prospects that exist for those arriving here. The ceilings on visa categories which the Minister can determine under this Bill apply to independent and concessional applicants. Preferential categories will not be affected. A research paper published by the Parliamentary Library Research Service in March this year entitled Migration Selection During the Recession stated:
The points tested selection system which applies to independent and concessional applicants . . . takes no account of demand within the Australian labour market.
The article concluded:
The major factor determining who migrates in current circumstances is `push' pressures in the source countries, not the state of the Australian labour market.

That is a concept to which we should pay a great deal of attention. This brings me to my earlier concerns about the politicisation of the migration program for which the potential does exist. The same research paper noted concerns that in 1989-90, Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs found it difficult to fill its concessional program partly because the skill level of applicants was lower than expected. It noted that Department management had been reluctant to alter the pass mark for concessional applicants because of concerns about the skill implications. That was at the time the Hawke Government shafted top management in the Department. There was a change of attitude in the Department in response to concerns from some ethnic interests and the selection system was changed for 1990-91.

PARA.TAB: Therein lies the danger of this Bill in the hands of a government that has demonstrated its ability and willingness to politicise the migration program. Migration selection must be for the national good and the benefit of those coming here. It cannot be for the political good of the Australian Labor Party. Every day we are confronted with the way the whole activity of this Government is perverted for the good of one man and one job—the job of Prime Minister for Paul Keating.

I turn to an example in November 1991 where, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics labour force estimates, 31.3 per cent of arrivals since January 1990 were unemployed. A total of 12.6 per cent of those migrants from English speaking backgrounds were unemployed compared with 42.5 per cent of those from non-English speaking backgrounds. This emphasises the point I made earlier, that if we are to have migrants coming to this country, whatever the level of intake, we have to provide the backup and the provision of English language services so that they can be assisted through English knowledge in obtaining employment. I quote further from the Migration Selection During the Recession research paper:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the rationale for continuing with a non-targeted skilled migration program is flawed. The expectation that general skilling of the work force will help with economic recovery is questioned. It is more likely that economic recovery will have to occur before conditions in the skilled labour markets improve. In the meantime skilled migration should be curtailed.

I say in conclusion that the coalition is proud of its support for a multicultural Australia. I make no apology for attacking multicultural politics and multicultural politicians. Our immigration program will serve the national interest, the good of all Australians, irrespective of their background—not those chosen to curry favour with the Labor Government as has been the sad history of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: IMMIGRATION, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ETHNIC AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—We are discussing tonight Migration Laws Amendment Bill 1992, which might come as a bit of a shock to people who are listening to the broadcast—the one or two who happen to be tuned in. The shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), addressed the legislation, the proposal, and the concept behind it. I thank him for his comments. However, there are a couple of points that I should correct him on in passing.
—Gently.

—Gently, as always. He made the point that the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) had suggested that there was no difference between the Government and the Opposition and that we were playing catch-up politics. He then went on to outline a range of ways in which we did, in fact, differ quite substantially. I think that brief explanation confirms the point that I made, so I will leave it at that.

PARA.TAB: The comments of the honourable member for Dundas regarding matters outside the area of this proposal, as always, will be taken on board and considered by me. This is an understanding which we have developed over some time. The fact that the Opposition and the Government sometimes agree does not necessarily mean that I have sold out or the Opposition has sold out. Unfortunately, some people are only too quick to come to that conclusion.

The numbers have been lowered as a result of very extensive consultations by me and by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, taking into account the economic situation that exists in the country today. The lowering of the program over the last few years from 140,000 to 80,000 is the result of very extensive consultations. In earlier times in this place I was probably known as a very high migration person, but once one gets into this portfolio and talks to people at the grassroots level, to business people and to State and local governments, and listens to what members of parliament on both sides say, one is then armed with a lot of information which, together with the statistical data that the Department collates in the course of a year, all goes towards helping one to make a decision.

I make no apology to anyone for the downward thrust in the numbers. It is the result of a legitimate range of decisions that the Government has come to. Those people who are critical should join me at some of the community meetings where I have been confronted by some of the issues that have been raised tonight, such as access to English programs and the unemployment levels that exist within certain groups in the community. It is those things, when one comes eyeball to eyeball with a constituent group that one happens to be talking too about its particular situation, that help one to make decisions such as these.

It is not a question of the Opposition leading, as one person is reported to have said; it is a question of well and truly documenting the discussions we have had and coming up with the figure of 80,000. Incidentally, that figure is not what the Opposition would introduce; its figure would be substantially lower. That is a policy which those opposite will have to live with, and no doubt they will. But it should be pointed out that when we had a policy of 110,000 the Opposition promoted a figure of around 70,000 net. That is the figure that we have ended up with—80,000 gross and 70,000 net.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly. We will probably end up with less than 70,000 net. So let us be careful about the claims we make. All I am saying to the House is that I have no difficulty—in case there are any doubters on either side of the chamber—in standing up anywhere and defending my decision to cut the program to 80,000, because I think it is justified.

PARA.TAB: I have just returned from overseas, where I visited a range of countries. I had no difficulty at all in explaining the reasons why we had cut the program. I said I expected that the program would hover around that number in the future until we were able as a nation to provide work opportunities for all of those who have come here in the post-war years and until we were able to give people coming to this country the opportunity to go to work and provide for their children in the way in which they wanted to.

The suggestion that we have made decisions aimed at pandering to some mystical migrant group is most untrue. I can only speak for myself, but I can assure the House that I have not in any way buckled under any pressure from any lobby group. I have listened and I have consulted, but no one group has been given any better access to the process over and above any others while I have been in this job.

A range of other speakers addressed this legislation. They were a bit wide of the mark, I might add. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), for argument's sake, said that he was very interested in my response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations. He is a member of that Committee, as is the shadow Minister and one or two others in the place who are here tonight.

I have outlined my attitude to the issue referred to by the right honourable member for New England, which was the most controversial of the recommendations in the report. However, like always, the Government is now in the process of considering that report. There is a laid-down process in which we respond to reports of that nature and, in keeping with the traditions of this place, we will stick very carefully to that.

I do not run away from comments attributed to me on the question of the Chinese students, the pre-Tiananmen Square group, which I have made in this place before. The matter of how the Government will respond to the report will be a matter for the Government. When that decision is taken, I will relay that view to the House. I remind some journalists who have made a couple of comments about my not making any remarks with regard to that Committee report that I have been out of the country for the last three weeks. However, if they cared to press a button on their computer, they would have been able to call up my previous comments in this place, where my position was put fairly clearly. A couple of Sydney-based journalists seem to have difficulty in doing that.

The right honourable member for New England also talked about the role of overseas posts and people working in those posts. During my visit overseas, we had a meeting in Ireland of the immigration officers from all of the posts in Europe and North Africa. We went through all of the changes that have been made in recent times. I can assure the right honourable member that they are all full bottle. He should not have too many problems with his constituents who come from that part of the globe. There will be similar discussions with the senior migration officers in the various posts in other regions around the world.

The officers are charged with a very difficult task and, having met quite a lot of them—perhaps most of them before they left to go overseas—I know that theirs is a very difficult job. They do not get a lot of thanks. I put it on the record that their conditions are normally very trying in terms of finding accommodation for themselves and their families and finding schooling for their children. In some posts there are a number of problems in terms of the client groups that they sometimes have to deal with. It is not all laughter and good times when working in an overseas post in immigration; there are certain problems and hardships that the officers have to endure, and I have nothing but admiration for the work that they do. I can assure the right honourable member for New England that they are well briefed on recent changes. I expect that, if he has to deal with the overseas posts, he will get 100 per cent service.

The right honourable member ranged into an area about refugees. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) made mention of lawyers. It is well known, and he is quite correct, that the language which I sometimes use to describe lawyers is not able to be used in here, and I will not test the friendship with the Chair—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only lawyers.

—Not only lawyers; that is true. The honourable member for Cowper ran into me in a lift the other night, unfortunately, and that has also been covered in the media. But we will not repeat that tonight.

PARA.TAB: The right honourable member for New England spoke of the need for the Department to be aware of situations when we return people so that their lives are not placed at risk. I do not know of any government—and you, Mr Deputy Chairman, as a former Minister, I am sure would agree—representing either side of the chamber which would have deliberately sent someone home to his or her country and placed that person in danger or put his or her life at risk. I am not aware of that. I certainly will not be doing that. If that is an assurance that the right honourable member for New England wants, I give it to him.

Another point that was made related to the question of decisions being made by the Government in some sort of attempt to win popularity. I have not set out to do that. Again I speak only for myself, but the Government has made a number of changes in terms of how immigration is being run. It has introduced user pays. There has been some criticism of that, but I make no apology to anybody for the changes we have made.

The fact is that a well-heeled business migrant ought to be able to make some contribution to the cost of himself and family learning English. I would have thought that was a reasonable proposition that would be supported by most people in this chamber, and certainly by most people in the community. It does two things. It makes those who can afford it pay most, and it also creates a vacancy for someone at the lower end of the economic scale to go into. Furthermore, if there is a need to bring some specialist into the country who has a skill that is not available here, why should the employer not meet the costs of educating that person?

On the question of user pays in the learning of English, again I think it is only fair that some very small contribution should be made when one considers the overall cost of 510 guaranteed hours that each person will now get for the first time. Some small cost at a few cents per lesson is not unreasonable, given that other people who wish to further their education—people who are being retrenched or, say, railway workers who are changing jobs—have to go to TAFE and make a small contribution towards the cost. So we have not ignored areas that traditionally have been considered sacred and unable to be touched. We have increased the fees for visas in line with the costs involved in processing people, and again in a very reasonable way.

The shadow Minister also touched on the matter of refugees and said he would leave his arguments to another day. I think it probably preferable that most of the comments made by honourable members in this debate about refugees be left until then. However, on my recent visit overseas, I had the opportunity of going to Hungary, Austria and Germany to look at people who were fleeing the troubles of the former Yugoslavia. I also went to Kenya, and to the border of Ethiopia and Somalia and talked to people in a camp there. It was a dreadful experience. So my commitment in this program in terms of refugees has always been to maintain and protect what I think is the most important part of the program—that is, the offshore refugee component of the migration program. I believe there can be no other component as important as that.

I take the point that the right honourable member for New England made in regard to the question of people lobbying in Australia and seeking refugee status. I think it is a legitimate fear for anybody to have. Although there have been a few bumpy periods, I believe that with the foreshadowed refinements referred to by the shadow Minister that will be introduced later this year, we have without a doubt the best situation in terms of controlling that area of any country in the world. People in this country scoff at that, but it happens to be true. Go to Germany, go to Hungary, go to Kenya, go to Turkey, go to Iran—where there are 2 1/2 million Afghanis—and look at the processes that they have. They do not have an immigration program, and in most cases they do not have a refugee processing arrangement.

We have had a problem. The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) is here and he knows this, because I have had lengthy discussions with him on the cost of all this. We have spent a long time trying to grapple with this situation, which no-one in this Parliament, clever as we all are, was able to predict. We have a problem and we have grappled with it. There will be more about that at a later date.

The question of lawyers was mentioned. There is a photograph that I take with me all around the world, wherever I go. I mention it today because I might not get another chance before something tragic happens. On the photo it says: `Suicide is just two steps away. You might as well jump'. The reason I raise that today is that the sign was on the door of the lawyers' interview room in Port Hedland, until it was discovered and photographed and then removed. Honourable members would have seen on television the people on the roof. They would be aware that other people have been reported in the press today talking about suicide. They would have heard the sort of half clever remarks made by people. I was supported by the shadow Minister on this matter. Here we are trying to stop people doing something stupid and anyone would think we were the two guilty ones.

That sort of irresponsibility is one of the reasons why I am just a bit cheesed off with some of the legal profession. It is not a question that some of them are also rip-off merchants and that we have had to try to contain them in the migration agents area. This topic was covered on the 7.30 Report tonight, and the legal profession says, `We can't be touched. Everybody else should be disciplined and controlled, but not us', said the man in the blue shirt. Well, bad luck for him. They are going to be. Everybody in this chamber knows who the main offenders are—some lawyers. So they have no special rate with me at all.

I mention the existence of that photograph today because I constantly live in fear, as do most of the departmental officers, that there are some people who, for other reasons and other agendas, are trying to wind up some of these people that we are desperately trying to process. We have had to put up with people saying, `Well, let's spin this out, because there is no work back in Melbourne. Let's see how long this can last', and threatening the Federal Court all the time. I repeat that it is a disgrace that a lawyer should take 17 months to lodge an application when the client concerned is in custody. But every time I rang and asked, `Why can't you do it?', I got threatened with some half smart, half clever remark about going to the Federal Court. That is the sort of problem we have been grappling with, and I think we are winning.

I resent the constant barrage of misrepresentation in the media by people with other agendas, knowing full well that in most cases neither the departmental officers nor I can defend ourselves because the matter is either before the court or the review committee. There will be a day of judgment when all this comes out, and I hope it does. It is about time the Australian community knew what some people are trying to do, and that is to deliberately set about to undermine the migration program and the refugee processing arrangements.

Now that I have got that off my chest, I wish to refer to some other matters about multiculturalism. I am proud to be an Australian and I am proud to be part of a multicultural society. I say to my friend the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) that people throughout Europe want to know about multiculturalism because in this country it is working. I do not agree with my good friend the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) on everything and this is one area where we fall out. He is wrong in his view and is wrong to knock multiculturalism. It is a great thing and we should be proud of it. When people from communities currently in dispute in what was called Yugoslavia—Serbs, Croatians, Bosnians, Macedonians—can march one behind the other in a recent procession in a city like Geelong, and indeed organise that procession, that is something we should be proud of in this country.
