TALK.START.PARA: —The Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1992 amends the Austudy and Abstudy schemes to introduce what the Government refers to as a financial supplement to both schemes. This supplement in fact is a loans scheme and allows students to trade in some or all of their Austudy or Abstudy grants for a loan of twice the size up to a limit of $4,000. The scheme will operate from 1 January 1993. The Bill also legislates for the automatic indexation of Austudy and Abstudy grants in line with inflation. The Opposition will not be opposing this legislation but now moves the following second reading amendment:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: "whilst not opposing the passage of the Bill, the House condemns the Government for its failure to adequately address the problems in the administration and targeting of student financial assistance to ensure that it is fair and accessible to all".

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

—This amendment draws attention to the Government's failure to take adequate action to target the financial assistance available under the scheme or to recover overpayments. One of the great difficulties in this area has been dragging the Government

SPEECH.PARA: to the point where the need for change has been recognised. The Opposition has sought consistently and constructively to create a climate where worthwhile reform of student financial assistance can take place, despite the unrelievedly partisan attitude which the Government has adopted.

PARA.TAB: In this year's Budget $1.3 billion has been allocated to student financial assistance through Austudy and a further $194m to assistance through Abstudy. The cost of Austudy and Abstudy exceeds the cost of the total Commonwealth program of grants to government schools and is equivalent to 30 per cent of the total Commonwealth funding for higher education. Student financial assistance can thus be seen as a very significant Commonwealth financial commitment. In fact, it constitutes some 19 per cent of total Commonwealth expenditure related to education.

The sheer scale of the student financial assistance program requires that it be subject to the closest scrutiny. Funds allocated to the program are not available for other educational purposes, and funds which are poorly targeted within the program are not available to help the students in greatest need. It is a matter of very high priority for this program, as it is indeed for all Commonwealth programs, that the efficiency and effectiveness of the program be rigorously assessed.

When the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training—of which the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), who will be speaking in this debate, is Deputy Chairman—brought down its report on student financial assistance in March 1991, the Committee expressed its great concern at that time that Austudy and Abstudy had never been properly evaluated. The report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee finds it disturbing that billions of dollars have been spent on programs for which the success or otherwise has never been assessed.
It drew attention to the fact that:
DEET's current performance indicators emphasise processing efficiency rather than program effectiveness.

The effectiveness of the program was difficult to evaluate because, as the Committee noted, its objectives were unclear. It was apparent that there were many students receiving Austudy who plainly were not in great financial need, while there were many other students in obvious financial need who were ineligible for aid under the rules of the program. Many of these were students in rural areas who were excluded from assistance by the operation of the asset test. In addition, it was evident from reports of the Auditor-General that substantial losses were occurring as a result of inadequate accounting practices, fraud and overpayments. DEET compliance surveys had found that between 12 per cent and 27 per cent of students were being overpaid. At the higher rate, overpayments would have totalled about $130m.

PARA.TAB: The coalition parties accepted then and accept today that a basic objective of student financial assistance should be that no student with the capacity and the will to continue his or her education should be prevented from doing so on financial grounds alone. This was an important principle, not merely on grounds of securing equality of educational opportunity but also in the public interest. All Australians lose if talented young people are prevented from realising their full potential simply because they cannot afford the direct costs and the loss of income which continuing with their education might entail. It was our view that, if this were the guiding objective for student financial assistance programs, the existing arrangements for those programs would require very significant modification.

In the Fightback program announced by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in November last year, the Liberal and National parties made clear their view that very obvious steps could and should have been taken to better target student financial assistance, to end the rorting of the system and to reduce overpayments. A number of measures were announced by the Opposition in Fightback to achieve these objectives.

One of the worst of the rorts occurred when well-to-do families arranged their financial affairs so as to reduce their taxable income, thus bringing them within the limits of the Austudy income test. In Fightback we undertook to replace the definition of income as taxable income with the concept of total remuneration, which would take account of fringe benefits and other income. Another rort occurred when parents signed a statutory declaration that they would no longer support their child, in order to make their child eligible for Austudy at the higher independent rate. This occurred, as did other rorts, under the exceptional circumstances provision of the Austudy regulations. This rort would be removed.

A significant efficiency and targeting problem was the cost of administering large numbers of small payments, which could not by any stretch of the imagination constitute the difference between a decision to pursue or not to pursue an education. We undertook to eliminate payments of less than $30 a week as being inconsistent with the objective of the Austudy scheme. In relation to overpayments and fraud, we undertook to implement much tighter benefit control procedures, with the objective of saving approximately $80m. Our objective in announcing these measures was not simply to demonstrate that a responsible government could readily save very large and very significant sums on the Austudy budget without reducing assistance to those who needed it most; we also believed it was necessary to effect such savings in order to provide improved assistance to those in real need. This was very much a part of the philosophy underpinning Fightback, a philosophy which has quite deliberately targeted increased assistance to those in the community in genuine need who have suffered under Labor.

One of the key decisions in this regard that we announced at the time was the decision to increase Austudy payments by 6 per cent for all eligible students. This increase would be well in excess of any price effects flowing from the tax reform program announced in Fightback and would constitute a real increase in the level of financial assistance to eligible students. In addition to that, we announced a range of other measures to improve financial assistance to students in obvious financial need, particularly those suffering from the drastic collapse in rural incomes who faced the prospect of being withdrawn from or having to withdraw from their education without additional financial assistance.

A key measure to assist such students, in our view, is a properly constructed hardship provision. Such a provision would recognise that many rural families are in a position of negative income and that any notional asset value attached to their properties would be totally misleading as an indicator of that property's income-earning potential. Accordingly, we announced that a coalition government would introduce a provision under which the asset test would be set to one side for families in extreme economic circumstances, and only the income test would apply. If families qualified under the income test in such circumstances, that would be sufficient for students in the family to receive Austudy.

Further, we were particularly conscious of the serious situation which had developed for many isolated families, with the decline in the real value of the boarding allowance for secondary students and the additional effect of the Government's introduction of an asset test on this scheme. In our view, the Government's policy had seriously compromised the opportunity for young people in isolated circumstances to access education, so we undertook to restore the real value of the boarding allowance to $2,500 and to abolish the asset test on the assistance for the isolated children scheme.

Beyond these measures, a range of other decisions announced at the time greatly enhanced the opportunity for students who worked part time to earn additional income and to save on essential expenses. These measures included raising the tax free threshold from $5,400 to $7,000; the abolition of petrol excise, which would save many students up to $11 every time they filled their tanks; and the abolition of a wholesale sales tax on items such as computers, electrical equipment and stationery, to name just a few.

It is also worth making the point that students whose incomes fall below the new tax threshold under Fightback's tax reform program, with the effect that the reductions in personal income tax will not fully compensate them for the price effect of the tax reform program, will be eligible for a tax credit, which will provide them with a direct monetary compensation at a rate greater than the expected price effect. These benefits would be in addition to the important benefits flowing to students from the improved financial arrangements for universities and schools and the increased availability of scholarships, including scholarships for students in need, that these arrangements would make possible.

Overall, we presented a very wide ranging program to improve access to education and to lift the quality and responsiveness of the education available to them. Beyond measures such as these, the Fightback program is a comprehensive strategy to create jobs—some two million jobs over the remainder of this decade. In many ways, that is the single most important thing that can be done to assist students. The Fightback program provides students with the prospect of greatly expanded opportunities for part time work if they want it while at university, with a much greater certainty of employment after graduation. The consequence of the direct financial decisions we announced in Fightback would be of direct and evident value to students, especially students in real financial need.

There are many aspects of the administration of Austudy and Abstudy which can be considered and dealt with only as part of a general review of the schemes. It remains a commitment of the coalition to fully review student financial assistance when in government to ensure that it is fair to all. I mention these various decisions because they demonstrate unmistakably how the coalition has led the public debate on Austudy reform and provided a context for a number of changes which the Government has since announced.

In the face of mounting criticism of the student financial assistance arrangements, the Department commissioned a consultant, Professor Bruce Chapman of the Centre for Economic Policy Research at the Australian National University, to report on the reform of Austudy. Dr Chapman consulted widely in the preparation of his report and presented his final options paper in April this year.

I have to say that Dr Chapman's work was not made any easier by an uncalled for intervention by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) after the publication of the first draft report. Dr Chapman's report provided documented confirmation of the major criticisms and concerns which the Opposition had expressed about the Austudy scheme. Dr Chapman concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: There is little doubt that the current arrangements sometimes target ineffectually, basically because there is relatively little sensitivity shown to the varied financial needs and circumstances of the potential clientele. The essential challenge for reform is to improve the targeting so as to ensure that the right amount of assistance is delivered to those who most need it.

Despite the Government's highly partisan attack on the coalition's proposals in the Fightback package for reform, Dr Chapman's report effectively confirmed the validity of those proposals. The report, for example, recognised that the manipulation of taxable income was a rort which allowed many students to receive support even though they had little need of it. Dr Chapman recommended that the Department and the Tax Office should investigate:
. . . whether or not there are administratively feasible ways to redefine the taxable income base for student income support purposes.
The report also recommended an increase in the minimum allowance payable to $20 per week.

PARA.TAB: One of the important achievements of Dr Chapman's report was to provide a cool and balanced assessment of the rationale for providing student financial assistance to both secondary and tertiary students. This was not easy to do in such an area of policy where people feel very strongly, but Dr Chapman is to be congratulated on the professional and sympathetic approach which his report demonstrates.
Dr Chapman sought to lay in his report a sound basis of principle for policy in this difficult area, and his analysis has very usefully contributed to this goal. Dr Chapman pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . governments need to be concerned with post-compulsory education because the education process delivers major benefits to society. The challenge is to understand the nature of these benefits, why government intervention might be needed to maximise them, and what forms this intervention should take to ensure maximum effectiveness.
He went on:
In policy terms, the key question is ultimately whether taxpayers or individuals should pay the costs, and in what proportions.
Dr Chapman pointed out:

The benefits of education take two basic forms: those which flow to society as a consequence of having a more educated population, and those which accrue directly and only to educated individuals. Respectively these benefits are known as spillover and private. Together they should be considered to be the social or (total) benefits of education.

The private benefits are both monetary and non-monetary. In the late 1980s the lifetime earnings advantage of completing tertiary education, as against completing school only, was estimated at about $300,000. The non-pecuniary benefits include a broadening of outlook, a training of the mind, a flexibility and an adaptability which is the product of higher education—or should be.

PARA.TAB: The spillover benefits include a much more informed public debate, less crime, more tolerance; the community benefits of research; higher tax revenue resulting from higher productivity and wages and enhanced prospects for competitiveness and economic growth.

The existence of both private and spillover benefits means that it is equitable that there be both private contributions to the cost of higher education as well as taxpayer contributions. Student financial assistance is necessary to secure the participation in higher education of students who might otherwise not be able to participate for financial reasons, with the consequence that we would all be deprived of the spillover benefits which result from their education.

Once having undertaken higher education, of course, there are private benefits which are derived by students themselves in the form of improved monetary and non-monetary rewards. Students who are poor usually become graduates who are not poor, and this should be taken into account in an equitable system of student financial assistance.

I should point out that to my knowledge the Government has remained silent on these principles stated so clearly in the Chapman report. It has not accepted nor rejected it, though in the Bill before the House this evening it is seeking to implement in part one of the major recommendations flowing from this report—the addition of a loan component to student financial assistance. Under this measure students will be offered the opportunity to commit additional resources of their own to the pursuit of their education, presumably in recognition of the fact that there are private benefits which will flow to them from their education. And while they are presently financially without resources or without adequate resources, in future they will have the income and the other benefits which make this short term investment on their own account worthwhile. The loans need to be repaid only when income in fact reaches a minimum level. There is no possibility of default under the arrangements set out in Dr Chapman's report and substantially adopted by the Government.

Let me make it quite clear that the coalition parties do not oppose a measure of this kind. Its great advantage is that it provides access to additional financial assistance which is at the option of the student. It thus allows much more accurate and non-bureaucratic targeting to help students in financial need. It is justified in principle because students seeking it will derive substantial private benefits from the use of these funds.

The Government's failure to acknowledge in any coherent way the arguments justifying this arrangement is not unexpected. The Government's whole approach to the financing of higher education is incoherent. If the Government were to accept Dr Chapman's argument in the terms in which he stated it, it would have to reconsider its nonsensical decision to prevent students investing in their own education—a right it gives to overseas students—by allowing Australian students to gain additional places at universities for fees.

Under the arrangements to be established by this Bill, the Government is prepared to allow students to invest further private resources once they are admitted, but it is not prepared to allow them to invest in the tertiary place itself—even though the universities have indicated that they would support students having this opportunity, and even though there are students who desperately want this opportunity. If it accepted the argument of Dr Chapman's report, the Government might also be prepared to allow more flexibility to universities in establishing the private valuation which students give to their education instead of setting a rigid fixed charge for all students.

The Higher Education Council, in its September advice to the Minister on planning for the 1993-95 triennium, found it impossible, on my reading, to provide a coherent rationale for the current policy, and it indicated that it would be exploring issues which the Government has refused to address. The Industry Commission last year concluded, of course, as we remember, that the Government's current framework was fundamentally `flawed'. We are seeing a government policy where political ideology is prevailing at enormous cost to students and to the nation. This Bill is just one more sign that this policy is in the process of collapsing around the Government's ears.

Since Fightback, the Government has summoned up the courage to adopt several of the coalition's proposals, at least in part. It moved quickly to adopt our policy to increase the real value of the boarding allowance for isolated children, though it has persisted with its determination to retain the asset test on the means tested portion, so there remains a significant difference in the policy of the Government and the Opposition on this matter. In the Budget, the Government acknowledged that there were savings to be made by redefining taxable income and including fringe benefits and by establishing a minimum payment level which it set at $20 a week. It even acknowledged that there were savings to be made by more effective action to recover overpayments, a matter which, I have to say, sadly the Minister denied at the time when the Fightback package was released. The Government tells us that it anticipates only about $7m from this source.

This is a matter which the Minister finds very hard to address. As I mentioned earlier in my speech, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training used estimates which the Department of Finance acknowledged could produce substantial savings. When we announced our target savings in Fightback, the Minister stated that he believed these were probably wholly irrecoverable. The Department of Finance put him right on that one, and indicated publicly in its comment on the Fightback proposals that it saw the possibility of at least $41m in savings. The Minister has come up with $7m. Judging from the Auditor-General's latest damning condemnation of the financial management of the Department, he should have been told to go away and come back with something more. But his vote is probably important in the Caucus.

In short, we have a government dragged to the post to establish a suitable framework for student financial assistance. Instead of a coherent system, we have a rolling set of piecemeal reforms, without any coherent analysis of the issues. There has not been a single significant speech on this topic by the Minister in the House.

In assessing the changes in this legislation, it remains significant that nothing whatever has been done by the Government to realistically open access to education for rural students who would be excluded from Austudy by the assets test. These students do not have access to the loans arrangement set up by the Government, despite the fact that the Chapman report suggested they should. The Government has still not adopted an adequate hardship provision of the kind proposed by the Liberal and National parties. Rural students remain a significantly disadvantaged group under this Government, and it is still totally out of touch with the pressing need to lift educational access and standards in this country. After we have seen so many statements criticising the Opposition and a complete failure by the Minister to provide this House with a coherent explanation of the Government's financing arrangements in higher education, I am afraid that we can expect nothing more from this Government during its term of office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tomorrow I will be presenting to the Clerk a petition from some of the people of Bega. The petition asks the House:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to adjust the parental income threshold entitlement to Austudy so that it is the same as the entitlement to family allowance.
The petition also asks the House:
. . . to grant a non means tested base allowance and travel allowance for tertiary students who leave their local area to study.

This is the second petition from the people of Bega that I have presented. I believe that the House needs to give attention to the petition. It is part of the consultation that the Government has undertaken over many years in improving the financial assistance methods in education. It is very important that we take into account all the views that come to us.

PARA.TAB: I believe that both the suggestions are well motivated. I can see some community objection to the second suggestion, which recommends a non-means tested base allowance and travel allowance, simply on the basis of the fact that when we came into government in 1983 there were considerable complaints from people about the tertiary education assistance scheme, which was known as TEAS. There were a considerable number of complaints about the fact that there was no assets test on TEAS. I can remember people on wages complaining to me that people who were on fairly low income but who had very high assets were able to obtain TEAS. They were instancing doctors' children, farmers' children and others who were obtaining TEAS. There were many complaints about that.

At that time there were also complaints about people who were receiving other non-means tested benefits. People were saying, `Why should people receive benefits when they are perfectly able to look after themselves?'. So I can see some problems with the second suggestion. But I believe the first suggestion needs to be given attention fairly urgently, because if we see people as our greatest resource it is important that we have a student income which is higher than unemployment benefits in order to encourage people to pursue education.

The suggestion which has been made to adjust the parental income threshold entitlement for Austudy so that it is the same as the entitlement for family allowance seems to me to be fair. But I can see why there are arguments against it. For instance, we are spending $6.5 billion on education and this suggestion would involve a very large increase on that. It would involve looking at the total income of government from taxation and working out just where such expenditure could be taken from. But it is important that we add value not only to our goods and commodities, but also to our education system and that is one important way of doing it.

It is true that Australia has close to the world's best student financial assistance scheme. Australia has one of the world's fairest and most equitable higher education systems. I recall a finance organisation appearing before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies and telling it about some of the things Australia could be doing in exporting to overseas markets.

Two of the items which it mentioned may surprise many people in Australia. One was health. It was stated that our health system ranked so high in the world that we ought to be marketing it to other countries and offering to set up a similar system there. There are many complaints about our health system, but of course they come mainly from people who have not suffered the health systems of other countries, such as the United States and Europe where people are paying out huge amounts of money for health. I recall reading about one farmer who lost his property because he had been in hospital for three months and simply did not have health insurance. That would not happen in Australia where we have compulsory health insurance.

In the area of education, it was suggested by the finance organisation that we ought to set up education systems in other countries. It suggested that it was well worth looking at establishing the Austudy system, for instance, in other countries. Since 1983, the number of secondary students on income support in Australia has increased 3 1/2 times—there are now 350 per cent more secondary students on income support. This is far fairer and more equitable than the system which existed in 1983. The number of people on tertiary benefits has increased by 125 per cent. The real value of maximum benefits paid has increased by 11 per cent for tertiary students and by 115 per cent for secondary students. It is no wonder that a lot more people are staying on at school.

That needs to happen because we no longer have what were called the `dead-end jobs'. In the days of the Depression we were able to say, `Let's put people out to work on the roads with shovels making bridges'. We now use far more equipment to do that work. Governments do not want to employ people to do that work; they want to employ machines. So we must have educated people. Of course, our main exports in the future will be in the information area and one of our main growth industries will be the information industry. So it is important that we take heed of that fact and educate more people.

There is still room for improvement. There are people in the Bega area, and in other areas, who are very unhappy about the existing system. Just because a poor person in the United States has to work at McDonald`s all night at $3 an hour to get his education, that is no reason why we should be satisfied—even though we have a better system in Australia. It is important that we continue this extensive public consultation. It is important that we continue to examine our system and improve on it, simply because we have made innovations in the education area. As a result, we have to put up with the fact that there are mistakes made occasionally and that there is room for improvement.
I want to comment on the amendment that the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) has moved. It states:

. . . the House condemns the Government for its failure to adequately address the problems in the administration and targeting of student financial assistance to ensure that it is fair and accessible to all.

SPEECH.PARA: This seems to me to be the very direction the Government is taking and the very direction that the Opposition is not taking. The Opposition asks us to accept a market approach based on the demands of the labour market. Universities and schools will compete for students. That is false competition. The real competition ought to be where it is. The competition should be within the demands of the labour market. The labour market should dictate the number of students coming in, rather than the universities competing with each other.

PARA.TAB: It is particularly important in poorer areas and in rural areas that we do not generate that false competition. Fees are the key element of the Opposition policy. When we consider that the average course fee is about $12,000 a year, that is a pretty high fee to pay. Its system involves vouchers which are to be earned on merit. But what about the different costs of courses? The medical course may cost $30,000; another course may cost $5,000 or $10,000. What are vouchers doing there? They are making it much more difficult for poorer students to take on the more expensive courses, whereas under Austudy they are able to take on those more expensive courses if they have the ability.

The Opposition policy really means hand-outs to the richest. I believe we ought to reject that. We ought to reject this amendment because it does not honestly point out the direction that the Government is taking, it certainly does not honestly point out the direction that members of the Opposition are taking, nor does it point out the fact that they have a policy involving loans to students. The honourable member for Goldstein was praising Dr Chapman. The sorts of suggestions that he was making were totally rejected by students throughout Australia. Representatives of the banks who have come before one of our committees of this Parliament have said that if there are to be loans, then they would require a commercial return.

The loan system was adopted in the United States. The United States Government has to put funds into the loan system to enable it to continue. The Opposition's policy has made no mention of putting extra funds in to bolster the loan system. Even Mrs Thatcher realised that, to adopt this system, would be to adopt a system which involved a lot of defaulting on the part of people who had taken up the loans. As well as that, it is not particularly fair to the people who take up the loans and have to pay back the full cost of their education—whether it is $12,000 or $30,000 a year. It is not fair. The system the Government has of paying back a portion of the education over time, provided that they are on a certain income, is much fairer.

The legislation before us is important in giving an option to some of these people who may not be eligible for Austudy. People who do not currently qualify for Austudy or Abstudy—about 50,000 tertiary students—would be eligible for a supplement provided the combined income of their parents was less than $50,000 per annum. They would be able to receive a supplement of about $2,000. There are people who would like to take advantage of that. I believe that that opens up the possibilities for children of parents who are unable or not prepared to pay for the full costs of some of the courses. It may well make a difference between a student being able to attempt a course or not attempt a course. So the improvements which have come to the student assistance scheme arose from the major review of Austudy which has involved the extensive public consultation that I have been talking about.

I am delighted that the Opposition has decided to support the legislation. It will give opportunities to students who do not have them at the moment. Even students who are receiving Austudy or Abstudy will be able to receive a trade-in on all or part of their grant up to a limit of $2,000 for double the amount of money—that is, up to $4,000—and that supplement will be provided at no real rate of interest. It is also entirely optional. I know there have been criticisms of this, but the point is that it is entirely optional.

The legislation is well worth while in broadening the scope of Austudy and Abstudy, enabling a lot of students who have not been able to take advantage of it previously to take advantage of it. But there is still room for improvement. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the number of Totally and Permanently Incapacitated (TPI) pensions granted dropped from 2300 in 1985-86 to 940 in 1990-91; if so, why.
(2) What was the effect on the number of applications for TPI pensions (a) granted and (b) rejected of each legislative change made since 6 June 1985.
(3) Why was each of the legislative changes referred to in part (2) made.
(4) Was a reduction in the number of TPI pensioners a reason for the legislative changes.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. In response to a similar question from the honourable member (Question No. 1293, Hansard of 25 February 1992, pp 2838-2839) I supplied the following figures for the years 1986-87 to 1990-91:

ANSWER.PARA: Year T&PI Grants

These figures included "continuations" (i.e. a veteran in receipt of special (T&PI) rate pension submitting an additional valid claim which does not affect the veteran's rate of pension) and, therefore, were overstated. The figures, excluding "continuations", for the five years are as under:
Year T&PI Grants
My previous answer gave the reason for the reduction in grants in 1986-87. Since then the level of grants has been fairly constant.

PARA.TAB: (2) The legislation was changed on two occasions affecting the criteria for special (T&PI) rate pensions since 6 June 1985.

The first change was to make the special (T&PI) rate pension payable for life. The change was announced in the 1987 Budget and was introduced retrospectively from the date of commencement of the VEA. The basis for the change was the Federal Court decisions in Smith, Wright and McGuire in which the court held that the special (T&PI) rate pension should not be payable for the whole of the veteran's life or indefinitely, but only for so long as he is not prevented from undertaking remunerative work by the service-related disability.

The second change to the legislation was a change to the required degree of incapacity. This was reduced from 100% to 70% in December 1988. The change was accompanied by a new provision that enabled a veteran to qualify where he or she met all the eligibility criteria at any point between the application date and the date of decision of the Commission or review body. The change resulted from a recommendation by the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee, following decisions of the Federal Court that indicated a misunderstanding of the intentions of the application day provisions.
The change to make these pensions payable for life would have had no impact on the number of grants or rejections.

The effect of the other changes would have been to increase the number of disability pensioners who were entitled to the special (T&PI) rate pension. Figures are not available on the number of pensions granted at the special (T&PI) rate resulting from this change.

The legislation requires a determining authority to consider the question of T&PI eligibility once the threshold of the degree of incapacity of 70% is reached. There is no need for a specific application from the veteran for the special (T&PI) rate pension to be made. There are, therefore, no statistics collected of rejections of the special (T&PI) rate.

(3) The change in the degree of incapacity from 100% to 70% was detailed in my speech in the House on 20 October 1988. The Government accepted the recommendations of the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee that a disability pensioner suffering a degree of incapacity of at least 70% was likely to be severely disabled and unable to continue working and should, therefore, be eligible for consideration of the special (T&PI) rate pension.

The reason for the legislative change concerning the special (T&PI) rate pension to be payable for life was to reflect the fact that since the inception of the T&PI pension in the 1920's no Government had ever taken steps to remove a T&PI pension from a veteran, except on the grounds of fraud, improved health or the capacity to undertake remunerative activity. The change was necessary in view of the view expressed by the Federal Court (see paragraph 2 above).

(4) No. In fact the December 1988 change made the granting of special (T&PI) rate pensions easier. Naturally the number of grants of special (T&PI) rate pensions must decline as the veteran population ages and leaves the work-force at a normal retiring age. Most veterans of World War II have retired. In addition it must be remembered that the veterans of WW II are dying at a greater rate than in the past and this reduces the number of possible claims. The veteran population eligible for disability pension who are younger than normal retiring age has reduced considerably between 1985-86 and 1990-91.

The introduction of Extreme Disablement Adjustment as an alternative for severely disabled veterans who because of advancing age or other reasons could not qualify for a T&PI rate pension, indicates that rather than looking for a reduction in T&PI pensions the Government has been keen to protect the interests of veterans. Similarly, the introduction of an "assessment period" is certainly a significant advantage to veterans applying for the special (T&PI) rate.

PARA.TAB: (10) What steps is the Government taking or proposing to take to implement fully the provisions of the international conventions referred to in the preceding parts to which Australia is a party.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The Australian Government takes seriously its obligations under international instruments and seeks to act in full conformity with these obligations.
(2) Yes.

(3) No. The Australian Government has been considering making the declaration under Article 14 and has undertaken consultations to that end with the States and Territories, as appropriate in a federal system. Since Australia has acceded to the first Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), there is no objection in principle to making the declaration to allow for a similar process under the racial convention. The Attorney-General has consulted with his State and Territory counterparts and a majority of States and Territories supported the making of the declaration. The Government is now giving detailed consideration to this matter, including consultations with Ministers to whose portfolio responsibilities the Convention is most relevant.
(4) Yes.
(5) No. This matter has been under consideration in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General for some years. On 11 May 1992 I wrote to the Attorney-General, Mr Michael Duffy, requesting

ANSWER.PARA: that Australia expeditiously pursue the making, of a declaration under Article 41. The Attorney-General is consulting with the States and Territories on this matter.

PARA.TAB: (6) Yes.

(7) No. The Australian Government has been considering making the declaration under Article 22 and is addressing the questions of consultation and consideration in a manner identical to that outlined in paragraph (3) above. Making of a declaration under Article 21 will be considered in conjunction with Article 41 of the ICCPR and the Attorney-General is consulting with the States and Territories concerning such a declaration. Again, in my letter of 11 May 1992 to the Attorney-General I requested that Australia expeditiously pursue the making of declarations under Articles 21 and 22.
(8) Yes. Australia signed Protocol 1 on 7 December 1978 and ratified the Protocol on 21 June 1991. The Protocol came into effect for Australia on 21 December 1991.
(9) Yes. Australia made the declaration on 13 September 1992 and is in the process of depositing the instrument with the Swiss Federal Council, which acts as depository for the Protocol.
(10) See preceding parts (3), (5), (7) and (9).
